Subject: ‚è≥ The Other 8 Hours
Body Text:
Hey friends,

ü•≥ Quick thing before we start - I'd love to hear what you think of LifeNotes. Take 5 minutes to share your feedback here (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TN-23pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3ljW9d_Psh25vtS5W4fHTDX5dC5-2W7StmlS7J8XXlV-XMKS7DtKYbW8zBtvn1DtW6tW12LY525l-RNBW8xKrSN2d7M9XW12BsRf7Dl-G-W7-2SzS68FR5BW6fv_ym1NMjwXW4xs5pJ6g81L8VKZQn15S7hdJN64XrVj6MG6nW4V1xcd6RcpWcV3DTNg5J11gYW3ylRkm1Pptj0W89v3Hq6Rkxs1W7FCd2Z4ZVsp6W49xln34BHQz_W4BSH2q16hZm6W2s5LS93dg6PTW7vsdx175-fHjN6nltD0t-PmWW2267PZ8gnx1Jf97qGcF04 ) (which has the chance of being featured on my new website)

A while ago, I stumbled on the idea of the ‚Äúother 8 hours‚Äù in Arnold Bennett‚Äôs timeless book ‚ÄúHow to Live on 24 Hours a Day‚Äù (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3nWW850bZv3vS9DcW2JsQmy1jBm55W1C703Q8x1c2tW5jJr5Q4BJlQ6W8HSWL48pq8f8W5lY6Sr7l5z5KW8xcccd7bsfH-W82wkfK38hvzrW4Wm2ZB2z_RdkW3DzPNl3k65jwW2l2tKn68Qt8tW4hB_YQ91n6lbV9gYj-7ghPYwW6YWkrX8FVfJgW247Q-_91K2D0W3JQJW55HZsB7W2r1cCc5xLS9SW7BjHgb70vLWzW6hyLqz868MZsW8z7VB16wwzGYW4Xcn9X96ZkQLW7tQH_n1-1Yp6dnD4DF04 ) . Here‚Äôs a quote that I love:

So let us begin to examine the budget of the day‚Äôs time. You say your day is already full to overflowing. How? You actually spend in earning your livelihood‚Äîhow much? Seven hours, on the average? And in actual sleep, seven? I will add two hours, and be generous. And I will defy you to account to me on the spur of the moment for the other eight hours.

In the book, our friend Arnold breaks down our daily 24 hours into three segments:

The first 8 hours - Sleep. Even the richest person in the world needs to sleep.

The next 8 hours - Work. Everyone needs to work. If you‚Äôre employed, you work. If you‚Äôre an entrepreneur, you work. If you‚Äôre a trust fund baby, you want to work. If you‚Äôre a parent, you do the work of the family and the household. If you‚Äôre free from having to work, you‚Äôre likely to eventually realise that you want to work anyway because it gives your life purpose.

But then we have the other 8 hours - for everything else.

What do we do with the other eight hours? How we use the other 8 hours is the difference between a life that we love, and a life that we don‚Äôt.

If I‚Äôm not intentional, it‚Äôs easy for the other 8 hours to look like this

- 2 hours playing World of Warcraft

2 hour scrolling on social media or watching YouTube videos

A few hours scrolling on the internet

A few more hours eating and chilling

And boom. Just like that, the other 8 hours are gone.

My ideal way of spending these other 8 hours actually looks something more like this:

- Learning (2 hours): dedicated time to learn something new - a language, guitar, music theory, coding a website, etc.
- Health (2 hours): going to the gym, taking long walks, playing padel and squash with the gang ;)
- Something social (3 hours): chilling and spending quality time with family and friends; hosting dinner parties
- Solo time (1 hour): journalling, reflecting, other things that people say are good for the soul (whatever that means)

Have a great week!

Ali xx

P.S. I'd love to hear what you like (or don't like!) about this newsletter. Take 5 minutes to share your feedback here (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TN-23pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3ljW9d_Psh25vtS5W4fHTDX5dC5-2W7StmlS7J8XXlV-XMKS7DtKYbW8zBtvn1DtW6tW12LY525l-RNBW8xKrSN2d7M9XW12BsRf7Dl-G-W7-2SzS68FR5BW6fv_ym1NMjwXW4xs5pJ6g81L8VKZQn15S7hdJN64XrVj6MG6nW4V1xcd6RcpWcV3DTNg5J11gYW3ylRkm1Pptj0W89v3Hq6Rkxs1W7FCd2Z4ZVsp6W49xln34BHQz_W4BSH2q16hZm6W2s5LS93dg6PTW7vsdx175-fHjN6nltD0t-PmWW2267PZ8gnx1Jf97qGcF04 ) :)

üß† Little Lessons, Infinite Impact - Brilliant (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3q7W2jWqtB3jLJjFW6t0RQN3b2kkgW44Jcfy622_ynW1rzvWp8zCTr6W9l7vBV6YfhhKW5LS0Z01wVZYTW496B_q5Sp1XsN1jnN2lyPv0RW51P0-t6kfLT1W8D-zcm6mQ1LBW2yVBYg73SqJVW82nFkV6WvmJQW2NKclV2bHGMpW5DpQcX5pMScfW2j6mCf3Xz9F0W6dxHYC7chH0qW3Nr94P8k_tL5W2fT3n46m4CmcW9cS5Lt2lTDHPW8nR6tf4-G-kCMr3DtYrvk_8N3Yc8RdwpTvwf2FrKmz04 )

One of the biggest level-ups for me since I started learning more about productivity has been realising that I can make big changes in my life by taking small actions. If you‚Äôve ever read James Clear‚Äôs massively popular book Atomic Habits, then you‚Äôll know that making little tweaks to your day can have a huge long-term impact.

This is especially true when it comes to learning something new. Cramming for an exam the night before rarely works, but carefully revising for a little while each day in the lead-up to the test means that the knowledge actually sticks. This is what makes Brilliant (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3q7W2jWqtB3jLJjFW6t0RQN3b2kkgW44Jcfy622_ynW1rzvWp8zCTr6W9l7vBV6YfhhKW5LS0Z01wVZYTW496B_q5Sp1XsN1jnN2lyPv0RW51P0-t6kfLT1W8D-zcm6mQ1LBW2yVBYg73SqJVW82nFkV6WvmJQW2NKclV2bHGMpW5DpQcX5pMScfW2j6mCf3Xz9F0W6dxHYC7chH0qW3Nr94P8k_tL5W2fT3n46m4CmcW9cS5Lt2lTDHPW8nR6tf4-G-kCMr3DtYrvk_8N3Yc8RdwpTvwf2FrKmz04 ) such an effective learning tool.

Brilliant (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3q7W2jWqtB3jLJjFW6t0RQN3b2kkgW44Jcfy622_ynW1rzvWp8zCTr6W9l7vBV6YfhhKW5LS0Z01wVZYTW496B_q5Sp1XsN1jnN2lyPv0RW51P0-t6kfLT1W8D-zcm6mQ1LBW2yVBYg73SqJVW82nFkV6WvmJQW2NKclV2bHGMpW5DpQcX5pMScfW2j6mCf3Xz9F0W6dxHYC7chH0qW3Nr94P8k_tL5W2fT3n46m4CmcW9cS5Lt2lTDHPW8nR6tf4-G-kCMr3DtYrvk_8N3Yc8RdwpTvwf2FrKmz04 ) is an app filled with thousands of interactive lessons on everything from maths, data analysis programming and AI. Brilliant (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3q7W2jWqtB3jLJjFW6t0RQN3b2kkgW44Jcfy622_ynW1rzvWp8zCTr6W9l7vBV6YfhhKW5LS0Z01wVZYTW496B_q5Sp1XsN1jnN2lyPv0RW51P0-t6kfLT1W8D-zcm6mQ1LBW2yVBYg73SqJVW82nFkV6WvmJQW2NKclV2bHGMpW5DpQcX5pMScfW2j6mCf3Xz9F0W6dxHYC7chH0qW3Nr94P8k_tL5W2fT3n46m4CmcW9cS5Lt2lTDHPW8nR6tf4-G-kCMr3DtYrvk_8N3Yc8RdwpTvwf2FrKmz04 ) teaches you concepts in a hands-on and enjoyable way, so you actually understand the most important principles of whatever you‚Äôre learning - whether it‚Äôs understanding ground-breaking technology, or getting to grips with the building blocks of maths.

Their lessons are fun, engaging, and speedy, so you‚Äôre never stuck memorising things for hours at a time. I love that I can add Brilliant (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VWhj044ZS0RyW6ZVGrj7MGpt7W35KrPN5nnfSvN6-TNZM3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3q7W2jWqtB3jLJjFW6t0RQN3b2kkgW44Jcfy622_ynW1rzvWp8zCTr6W9l7vBV6YfhhKW5LS0Z01wVZYTW496B_q5Sp1XsN1jnN2lyPv0RW51P0-t6kfLT1W8D-zcm6mQ1LBW2yVBYg73SqJVW82nFkV6WvmJQW2NKclV2bHGMpW5DpQcX5pMScfW2j6mCf3Xz9F0W6dxHYC7chH0qW3Nr94P8k_tL5W2fT3n46m4CmcW9cS5Lt2lTDHPW8nR6tf4-G-kCMr3DtYrvk_8N3Yc8RdwpTvwf2FrKmz04 ) into my daily routine, finishing a lesson while I have my morning coffee, or rounding out my day with learning just before bed.

Subject: Shampoo recipe
Body Text:
Yes, there are additional herbs from various cultures that can enhance the
nourishing and treatment properties of your shampoo for type 4C hair. Here
are some additional herbs to consider:

### African Herbs
1. **Chebe Powder**: Known for its hair strengthening properties, chebe
helps prevent breakage and promotes length retention.
2. **Moringa Leaf Powder**: Rich in vitamins and minerals, moringa
nourishes the scalp and promotes healthy hair growth.
3. **Hibiscus Extract**: Provides deep conditioning, helps to prevent hair
loss, and promotes hair growth.
4. **Baobab Oil**: Moisturizes the hair and scalp, provides shine, and
improves elasticity.
5. **Rooibos Extract**: Rich in antioxidants, rooibos strengthens hair and
promotes healthy growth.

### Additional Herbs
1. **Nettle Extract**: Known for its high mineral content, nettle
strengthens hair and promotes growth.
2. **Rosemary Extract**: Stimulates hair follicles, promotes circulation to
the scalp, and helps with dandruff.
3. **Lavender Extract**: Known for its soothing properties, lavender also
helps with scalp health and hair growth.
4. **Sage Extract**: Strengthens hair and stimulates growth.
5. **Green Tea Extract**: Rich in antioxidants, green tea promotes scalp
health and hair growth.

### Updated Ingredient List for Amazon
1. Decyl Glucoside
2. Coco Glucoside
3. Polyquaternium-10
4. Hydrolyzed Silk Protein
5. Glycerin
6. Panthenol (Pro-Vitamin B5)
7. Dimethicone
8. Jojoba Oil
9. Xanthan Gum
10. Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
11. Citric Acid
12. Distilled Water
13. Phenoxyethanol (Preservative)
14. Ethylhexylglycerin (Preservative)
15. Sodium Benzoate (Preservative)
16. Potassium Sorbate (Preservative)
17. Fragrance or Essential Oils (optional)
18. Aloe Vera Gel
19. Shea Butter
20. Argan Oil
21. Marshmallow Root Extract
22. Honeyquat
23. Silk Amino Acids
24. Babassu Oil
25. Amla Extract
26. Bhringraj Extract
27. Brahmi Extract
28. Neem Extract
29. Fenugreek Extract
30. Ashwagandha Extract
31. Chebe Powder
32. Moringa Leaf Powder
33. Hibiscus Extract
34. Baobab Oil
35. Rooibos Extract
36. Nettle Extract
37. Rosemary Extract
38. Lavender Extract
39. Sage Extract
40. Green Tea Extract

### Instructions for Manufacturing with Additional Herbs
1. **Mix Surfactants**:
   - In a large mixing tank, combine Decyl Glucoside and Coco Glucoside.
Mix until uniform.

2. **Add Conditioning Agents**:
   - Slowly add Polyquaternium-10, Hydrolyzed Silk Protein, and Silk Amino
Acids while stirring continuously to ensure even dispersion.

3. **Incorporate Moisturizers and Emollients**:
   - Add Glycerin, Panthenol, Dimethicone, Jojoba Oil, Aloe Vera Gel, Shea
Butter, Argan Oil, Babassu Oil, and Honeyquat. Mix until fully incorporated.

4. **Blend Thickeners**:
   - Gradually add Xanthan Gum and Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
while mixing continuously to prevent clumping. Allow the mixture to hydrate
and thicken.

5. **Add Herbal Extracts and Powders**:
   - Add Amla Extract, Bhringraj Extract, Brahmi Extract, Neem Extract,
Fenugreek Extract, Ashwagandha Extract, Chebe Powder, Moringa Leaf Powder,
Hibiscus Extract, Baobab Oil, Rooibos Extract, Nettle Extract, Rosemary
Extract, Lavender Extract, Sage Extract, and Green Tea Extract. Ensure
thorough mixing to evenly distribute these ingredients.

6. **Adjust pH**:
   - Measure the pH of the mixture and adjust to 5.0-5.5 using Citric Acid.
This pH range is optimal for hair and scalp health.

7. **Add Water**:
   - Slowly add distilled water while mixing to achieve the desired
consistency.

8. **Add Preservatives**:
   - This step should be done by the manufacturer. Ensure proper
preservation by adding recommended preservatives like Phenoxyethanol and
Ethylhexylglycerin.

9. **Fragrance (Optional)**:
   - If using, add fragrance or essential oils at this stage and mix
thoroughly.

10. **Quality Control and Packaging**:
    - Conduct quality control tests to ensure the product meets all
specifications.
    - Package the shampoo in appropriate containers, ensuring they are
sealed properly for shipment.

By incorporating these additional herbs, your shampoo will provide even
more nourishment, moisture, and treatment benefits, making it particularly
beneficial for type 4C hair and helping your product stand out in the
market.

Subject: ‚ù§Ô∏è My Exclusive Q&A¬†
Body Text:
Hey Candace,

Last week, I hosted a 60 minute Q&A Group Coaching Session exclusively for members of Productivity Lab (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3nPN4kKj7cTN72fW85VhTh3Jb6XDW8V8PnW1VBxs6W1JfgxZ8X117NF4SH-JyyRRfW5bztxC3TPV6-W4FrCTb8_frxJW5fmnbZ1XSbVKW6GWXmm2rdXHRW4lR-ZQ7--5hsN7B-CypXYLfRW1655849klx6gW8Jv2sL2yX7hnW2lvKrg2PZ7jVW6BLTnb8GjZ8pW2pFZhs7-RW-4W7BNZmD8CScMhW5YWLZw2Tym6pW8rWpc91wKj7VVFCdPF1d9BK3W7RN36d6Pj6fpW2LXnjG5N_j0DW6Jybq-5TRTZsW2j-p_D2w-pNGf3-kN4R04 ) , so I thought I'd share some of the most valuable takeaways with you here üòú

By the way, if you don't want to miss my next Group Coaching session, you can join Productivity Lab here:

Join Productivity Lab
(https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3nPN4kKj7cTN72fW85VhTh3Jb6XDW8V8PnW1VBxs6W1JfgxZ8X117NF4SH-JyyRRfW5bztxC3TPV6-W4FrCTb8_frxJW5fmnbZ1XSbVKW6GWXmm2rdXHRW4lR-ZQ7--5hsN7B-CypXYLfRW1655849klx6gW8Jv2sL2yX7hnW2lvKrg2PZ7jVW6BLTnb8GjZ8pW2pFZhs7-RW-4W7BNZmD8CScMhW5YWLZw2Tym6pW8rWpc91wKj7VVFCdPF1d9BK3W7RN36d6Pj6fpW2LXnjG5N_j0DW6Jybq-5TRTZsW2j-p_D2w-pNGf3-kN4R04 )

1. ‚ÄúReflect, Don‚Äôt React‚Äù for Lasting Productivity

Most of us spend our days reacting to the endless stream of tasks, messages, and demands. Instead of reacting to every email ping or Slack notification, block out time to reflect.

I personally use Sunday evenings to review my week. And I don‚Äôt just glance at my to-do list, I ask myself: ‚ÄúWhat did I accomplish that really moved the needle?‚Äù Then I align my focus for the week ahead.

One member shared how they‚Äôve started using Productivity Lab's Weekly Reflection Rituals (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3p2W902Xt754f70TW38LFk05n6bNvW3GmHsB63KKrvW90jh5l54775WW6q91jS2H4rQGW115pWC1QHT21W5tcnhS90p3QcV9yvL42j_q9DW7xs13c72ZdLhW7ryNfG3YgBPPW66hyXS7CqKKcW4_LGXW36_bx2W8M3fxz5YCmy7W1CxdQN6P77d5W9cCKbl2rm3dWVVT3VB37t2ltW5lf3408G1gfTN69FyyMTnrSSW4xTlrw76l437W5zWHMR22zphDW4Cdg4y2qYTmPVWsmH31Vl0ZQW747hHy6VfwrTW2LLk_t82BJwbf4LrLN604 ) to ask themselves, "What 3 things brought me the most joy last week?" This simple reflection helps them prioritise tasks that align with their values and make work feel more rewarding.

2. Energy is Everything: Protect Your Focus Hours

We all have that one time of day when we feel like we can conquer the world.

For me, it‚Äôs early mornings - those precious, quiet hours where distractions are minimal, and my energy is at its peak. I use this time for deep work, like scripting videos or outlining new projects.

One Lab member, inspired by this, has begun scheduling their creative tasks for late afternoons when their energy spikes. They even added a ‚ÄúDo Not Disturb‚Äù sign on their door and turned off notifications to protect their focus bubble.

Protecting your focus hours is crucial - it‚Äôs when the magic happens ‚ú®

3. ‚ÄúSmall Wins‚Äù Build Big Momentum

Celebrate small wins.

When I was building my YouTube channel (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tH3pyd0W7Y8-PT6lZ3nfW2L4m8P4fmmdXW4VhNnQ6l6fGlW6q0Xzm6XspC9W5hRknn51VcRmN3bcJzKYplCmW4zH6n_7XLgcDN3HY9WQQPz3yW5NdVTG5mylWsW4Y2yK_7C56LfW8Y2QQf851nD6VDXS725tFFgZW3TDkzM4ctf1FW2LRgfz3fd9gBW6d8VD16T76wxW6kfqYk45TKFHW69BYlF4j7ZCyW8FTqrx3Sc9XTW5G0Snq6G7z8DW1Kg8Cf2YWCSKW2ydgV185-l8vVc3dVJ2zgYywV1xB0P2_0LgcW9hxW5X3cB-FjW7fzJzy3hyLcwW44fm1p3h3LBSW1WKFCw3M-qHwf4_qttq04 ) , I didn‚Äôt focus on hitting 1 million subscribers right away. Instead, I celebrated my first 100, then 1,000. Every time I hit a new milestone, I took a moment to acknowledge it.

One member shared how they apply this concept during Productivity Lab's daily Focus Labs (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3p2W902Xt754f70TW38LFk05n6bNvW3GmHsB63KKrvW90jh5l54775WW6q91jS2H4rQGW115pWC1QHT21W5tcnhS90p3QcV9yvL42j_q9DW7xs13c72ZdLhW7ryNfG3YgBPPW66hyXS7CqKKcW4_LGXW36_bx2W8M3fxz5YCmy7W1CxdQN6P77d5W9cCKbl2rm3dWVVT3VB37t2ltW5lf3408G1gfTN69FyyMTnrSSW4xTlrw76l437W5zWHMR22zphDW4Cdg4y2qYTmPVWsmH31Vl0ZQW747hHy6VfwrTW2LLk_t82BJwbf4LrLN604 ) .

They set mini-goals for each session, like writing 200 words or brainstorming for 10 minutes. These small wins keep them motivated and create momentum to tackle bigger tasks. It‚Äôs not about getting everything done at once - it‚Äôs about building momentum through consistent action.

4. The Power of Play: Making Work Fun Again

I‚Äôm all about finding ways to make work more enjoyable. In the Q&A, I shared how I gamify some of my tasks to bring a sense of play.

For example, when I write YouTube scripts, I set a 30-minute timer and try to "beat the clock" by drafting as much as I can without overthinking. It turns a task that could feel daunting into a fun challenge, and by the end, I‚Äôve often written more than expected.

One member loved this idea and applied it to their client calls - they had the idea of creating a ‚ÄúBingo board‚Äù with specific goals, like getting feedback or closing a sale, and checked off items as they hit them during the week.

Another member applied it to creative brainstorming sessions by setting up a ‚Äúcreative race‚Äù with a coworker to see who could come up with five new ideas for their projects in under 20 minutes. Not only did this add a playful vibe, but it also sparked some of their best ideas.

Turning work into a game keeps it light and energising, especially when it would otherwise feel like a grind.

5. Leverage Accountability to Stay Consistent

If there‚Äôs one thing that keeps me on track, it‚Äôs accountability.

I shared during the session how I used to struggle with consistency when I first started growing my YouTube channel. So, I made a pact with a friend to send them a weekly update on my progress. It wasn‚Äôt about perfection - it was about showing up.

In Productivity Lab (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3p2W902Xt754f70TW38LFk05n6bNvW3GmHsB63KKrvW90jh5l54775WW6q91jS2H4rQGW115pWC1QHT21W5tcnhS90p3QcV9yvL42j_q9DW7xs13c72ZdLhW7ryNfG3YgBPPW66hyXS7CqKKcW4_LGXW36_bx2W8M3fxz5YCmy7W1CxdQN6P77d5W9cCKbl2rm3dWVVT3VB37t2ltW5lf3408G1gfTN69FyyMTnrSSW4xTlrw76l437W5zWHMR22zphDW4Cdg4y2qYTmPVWsmH31Vl0ZQW747hHy6VfwrTW2LLk_t82BJwbf4LrLN604 ) , we give you the opportunity to connect with life minded people, and find an accountability buddy to help you stay on track.

One Lab member shared how their accountability buddy helped them break through a plateau. They would check in weekly on their goals and even celebrate wins together, creating a sense of progress and community.

The bottom line is that having someone in your corner makes a world of difference.

If any of these tips sound like exactly what you need, you‚Äôre going to love what we do inside Productivity Lab (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3p2W902Xt754f70TW38LFk05n6bNvW3GmHsB63KKrvW90jh5l54775WW6q91jS2H4rQGW115pWC1QHT21W5tcnhS90p3QcV9yvL42j_q9DW7xs13c72ZdLhW7ryNfG3YgBPPW66hyXS7CqKKcW4_LGXW36_bx2W8M3fxz5YCmy7W1CxdQN6P77d5W9cCKbl2rm3dWVVT3VB37t2ltW5lf3408G1gfTN69FyyMTnrSSW4xTlrw76l437W5zWHMR22zphDW4Cdg4y2qYTmPVWsmH31Vl0ZQW747hHy6VfwrTW2LLk_t82BJwbf4LrLN604 ) . These are just a few of the strategies our members are using to double their productivity and feel more energised while doing what matters most to them.

Join the Productivity Lab today, and you‚Äôll get access to exclusive expert-led workshops, daily co-working sessions, tons of productivity resources, and a vibrant community that makes staying productive a whole lot easier (and way more fun).

Join Productivity Lab
(https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VX63c978L1xWW1gllLQ7JN4BKW4Rs6st5mdd5GN1KM5tn3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3nPN4kKj7cTN72fW85VhTh3Jb6XDW8V8PnW1VBxs6W1JfgxZ8X117NF4SH-JyyRRfW5bztxC3TPV6-W4FrCTb8_frxJW5fmnbZ1XSbVKW6GWXmm2rdXHRW4lR-ZQ7--5hsN7B-CypXYLfRW1655849klx6gW8Jv2sL2yX7hnW2lvKrg2PZ7jVW6BLTnb8GjZ8pW2pFZhs7-RW-4W7BNZmD8CScMhW5YWLZw2Tym6pW8rWpc91wKj7VVFCdPF1d9BK3W7RN36d6Pj6fpW2LXnjG5N_j0DW6Jybq-5TRTZsW2j-p_D2w-pNGf3-kN4R04 )

See you inside!

Ali xx

P.S. Next week, we're hosting a members-only exclusive 90-minute Q&A session with storytelling master and productivity expert Matthew Dicks! Get ready to dive into storytelling, marketing, and leadership tips that will transform the way you communicate. Don‚Äôt miss it!

It took me 10 years to make my first million dollars as a digital writer.

But my second million? That only took 10 months.

So I just dropped a video explaining the 10 rules I followed to do this so you can write your way to wealth faster than I did.

In it, I break down:

‚Ä¢ Why telling a great story is only half the answer to becoming a rich & successful writer
‚Ä¢ The character trait you need to build a lucrative writing career (hint: it's not "genius")
‚Ä¢ Why, if you're charging per word, you'll never have a lucrative writing career (and what to do instead)

Check it out here: https://tapthe.link/BLFJJ0BXO

And if you find it helpful, please let me know in the YouTube comments what your biggest takeaway was‚Äîwould love to hear it!

Chat soon,

Cole ( Subject: Re: Shampoo recipe
Body Text:
ARYUVEDIC AFRICAN AND 4C HAIRCARE

On Sat, Jul 6, 2024, 2:04‚ÄØPM Candace Grant <aicoaching2025@gmail.com> wrote:

> Yes, there are additional herbs from various cultures that can enhance the
> nourishing and treatment properties of your shampoo for type 4C hair. Here
> are some additional herbs to consider:
>
> ### African Herbs
> 1. **Chebe Powder**: Known for its hair strengthening properties, chebe
> helps prevent breakage and promotes length retention.
> 2. **Moringa Leaf Powder**: Rich in vitamins and minerals, moringa
> nourishes the scalp and promotes healthy hair growth.
> 3. **Hibiscus Extract**: Provides deep conditioning, helps to prevent hair
> loss, and promotes hair growth.
> 4. **Baobab Oil**: Moisturizes the hair and scalp, provides shine, and
> improves elasticity.
> 5. **Rooibos Extract**: Rich in antioxidants, rooibos strengthens hair and
> promotes healthy growth.
>
> ### Additional Herbs
> 1. **Nettle Extract**: Known for its high mineral content, nettle
> strengthens hair and promotes growth.
> 2. **Rosemary Extract**: Stimulates hair follicles, promotes circulation
> to the scalp, and helps with dandruff.
> 3. **Lavender Extract**: Known for its soothing properties, lavender also
> helps with scalp health and hair growth.
> 4. **Sage Extract**: Strengthens hair and stimulates growth.
> 5. **Green Tea Extract**: Rich in antioxidants, green tea promotes scalp
> health and hair growth.
>
> ### Updated Ingredient List for Amazon
> 1. Decyl Glucoside
> 2. Coco Glucoside
> 3. Polyquaternium-10
> 4. Hydrolyzed Silk Protein
> 5. Glycerin
> 6. Panthenol (Pro-Vitamin B5)
> 7. Dimethicone
> 8. Jojoba Oil
> 9. Xanthan Gum
> 10. Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
> 11. Citric Acid
> 12. Distilled Water
> 13. Phenoxyethanol (Preservative)
> 14. Ethylhexylglycerin (Preservative)
> 15. Sodium Benzoate (Preservative)
> 16. Potassium Sorbate (Preservative)
> 17. Fragrance or Essential Oils (optional)
> 18. Aloe Vera Gel
> 19. Shea Butter
> 20. Argan Oil
> 21. Marshmallow Root Extract
> 22. Honeyquat
> 23. Silk Amino Acids
> 24. Babassu Oil
> 25. Amla Extract
> 26. Bhringraj Extract
> 27. Brahmi Extract
> 28. Neem Extract
> 29. Fenugreek Extract
> 30. Ashwagandha Extract
> 31. Chebe Powder
> 32. Moringa Leaf Powder
> 33. Hibiscus Extract
> 34. Baobab Oil
> 35. Rooibos Extract
> 36. Nettle Extract
> 37. Rosemary Extract
> 38. Lavender Extract
> 39. Sage Extract
> 40. Green Tea Extract
>
> ### Instructions for Manufacturing with Additional Herbs
> 1. **Mix Surfactants**:
>    - In a large mixing tank, combine Decyl Glucoside and Coco Glucoside.
> Mix until uniform.
>
> 2. **Add Conditioning Agents**:
>    - Slowly add Polyquaternium-10, Hydrolyzed Silk Protein, and Silk Amino
> Acids while stirring continuously to ensure even dispersion.
>
> 3. **Incorporate Moisturizers and Emollients**:
>    - Add Glycerin, Panthenol, Dimethicone, Jojoba Oil, Aloe Vera Gel, Shea
> Butter, Argan Oil, Babassu Oil, and Honeyquat. Mix until fully incorporated.
>
> 4. **Blend Thickeners**:
>    - Gradually add Xanthan Gum and Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
> while mixing continuously to prevent clumping. Allow the mixture to hydrate
> and thicken.
>
> 5. **Add Herbal Extracts and Powders**:
>    - Add Amla Extract, Bhringraj Extract, Brahmi Extract, Neem Extract,
> Fenugreek Extract, Ashwagandha Extract, Chebe Powder, Moringa Leaf Powder,
> Hibiscus Extract, Baobab Oil, Rooibos Extract, Nettle Extract, Rosemary
> Extract, Lavender Extract, Sage Extract, and Green Tea Extract. Ensure
> thorough mixing to evenly distribute these ingredients.
>
> 6. **Adjust pH**:
>    - Measure the pH of the mixture and adjust to 5.0-5.5 using Citric
> Acid. This pH range is optimal for hair and scalp health.
>
> 7. **Add Water**:
>    - Slowly add distilled water while mixing to achieve the desired
> consistency.
>
> 8. **Add Preservatives**:
>    - This step should be done by the manufacturer. Ensure proper
> preservation by adding recommended preservatives like Phenoxyethanol and
> Ethylhexylglycerin.
>
> 9. **Fragrance (Optional)**:
>    - If using, add fragrance or essential oils at this stage and mix
> thoroughly.
>
> 10. **Quality Control and Packaging**:
>     - Conduct quality control tests to ensure the product meets all
> specifications.
>     - Package the shampoo in appropriate containers, ensuring they are
> sealed properly for shipment.
>
> By incorporating these additional herbs, your shampoo will provide even
> more nourishment, moisture, and treatment benefits, making it particularly
> beneficial for type 4C hair and helping your product stand out in the
> market.
>

Subject: Why Live Events Are Crucial in the Creator Economy
Body Text:
Today we‚Äôre diving into why live events are such a big deal for both creators and brands

View in browser (https://emails.sequence-events.com/e3t/Ctc/WZ+113/csGbh04/VX17SF983FwSW18xSgg2ZxN_bW95j2m75mP7MmN1qZLrC5jGjMW6N1X8z6lZ3pxW1VNydf8lXDDqW3RVWcJ4fxf6vW5F7K7T1vb3B_W1t9RSc5d7QlrW2rDNPK4Vc5CPW2bfQ887Lb29yW3jJYTm2vl6t-W8Q3jVx6sLfZcW8w7ks_2w6315VyMyn04Fk2dmW60CQqx1qjxjBVRR6jn7pTMkqW4R1Phk8sXKntW5hxGp07fVZq2W1-pqL93cq0p5W5H3bcT2LQS3RW3f1rk4168PznW60RLWz56Q5f3W4NWtyh6VpPT2W5Bv6x23TSQH-W8vSQwG8j6vHnW4qf6zh343nN4W3Ygk8s204v_tW4RnpB_1M5lqlW61tJqP8Lp9tSW6j07F16RX_7TW1M2MB_6V_MGRN5T3YQ-3W1CbW4cwBRS4Sv1w5W7xzNrF1zC8q0W8yT1wF3StxgTW7-K18W37W3LGW7vXLST7tJq9qW4_Fphw8C6XqHW3l4Fdm7Y1spWW8rVPn194DLThN1ggdQYwwT42W1k1Z4J2lMb4Zd2bZ0404 )

Why Live Events Are Crucial in the Creator Economy

In recent years, the creator economy ‚Äî a marketing model where creators or influencers use social media and other digital platforms to create content, engage with their audiences, and most importantly, monetize those creations‚Äîhas exploded into a powerful ecosystem. This shift has totally changed the game for brands, too, giving them new ways to reach consumers and for influencers to build even stronger relationships with their communities.

One of the most exciting (and sometimes overlooked) tools in this booming space? Live events! Whether in-person or virtual, events can help creators grow, build trust with their fans, and bring in new revenue streams. For brands, meanwhile, live events are a great opportunity to team up with influencers and connect with people in a real, authentic way.

Today, we‚Äôre diving into why live events are such a big deal for both creators and brands. Read more‚Ä¶

Subject: ü§î 5 Quotes I‚Äôve been Reflecting on & Book Recommendations
Body Text:
Hey Candace,

Last week, I asked y‚Äôall for some book series recommendations.
Big thank you to the 200 of you who replied, with 164 different
series recommendations. At the bottom of this email, I‚Äôve listed
the top 10, in case you‚Äôre looking for some fiction
recommendations :)

Anyway, I don‚Äôt feel like I have anything useful to say this week
lol, so in addition to the book recommendations below, here are 5
quotes from various sources that I‚Äôve been reflecting on recently
üëá

1 - From Meditations for Mortals (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/wnh2h6uq460x8zfl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL21lZGl0YXRpb25zZm9ybW9ydGFscw==
) by Oliver Burkeman

Many people these days report the feeling that they begin each
morning in a kind of ‚Äòproductivity debt‚Äô, which they must
struggle to pay off over the course of the day, in hopes of
returning to a zero balance by the time evening comes. If they
fail ‚Äì or worse, don‚Äôt even try ‚Äì it‚Äôs as though they haven‚Äôt
quite justified their existence on the planet. If this describes
you, there‚Äôs a good chance that like me you belong to the gloomy
bunch psychologists label ‚Äòinsecure overachievers‚Äô, which is a
diplomatic way of saying that our accomplishments, impressive as
they may sometimes be, are driven ultimately by feelings of
inadequacy.
2 - From Die with Zero (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/reh8h9um7z6wk9b6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL3pRNlA=
) by Bill Perkins, referencing The Top 5 Regrets of the Dying (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/08hwhgu2xrlgnoap/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL1ZFb0lL
) by palliative care nurse Bronnie Ware

Along those lines, the second regret‚Äîand actually the top regret
among Ware‚Äôs male patients‚Äîwas this: ‚ÄúI wish I had not worked so
hard.‚Äù That hits right at the heart of what I‚Äôm preaching. ‚ÄúAll
of the men I nursed deeply regretted spending so much of their
lives on the treadmill of a work existence,‚Äù Ware writes. Women
had this regret, too, but, as Ware points out, her patients were
from an older generation, when fewer women worked outside the
home. And when people say they regret working so hard, they are
not talking about the hard work of raising children; they are
talking about working to make a living to pay the bills and, as a
result, missing ‚Äútheir children‚Äôs youth and their partner‚Äôs
companionship.‚Äù
3 - From The Second Mountain (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/8ghqh3uo3nrqw2bl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL1FjNFBDMg==
) by David Brooks

The natural tendency is to put oneself at the center of any
activity. To ask, How am I doing? That question is fine to ask
once. But it becomes paralyzing if you ask it all the time. A
pitcher who is thinking about how he is pitching cannot pitch
well. His focus is on self, not the task. ‚ÄúIn any hard
discipline, whether it be gardening, structural engineering, or
Russian,‚Äù the philosopher and motorcycle mechanic Matthew
Crawford writes, ‚Äúone submits to things that have their own
intractable ways.‚Äù
4 - From How to Live on 24 Hours a Day (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/vqh3hmuo4rwem4hw/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL1J0NEM=
) by Arnold Bennett. This quote is the ultimate secret to time
management, on how to make time to do all the things you need to
(and want to) do:

I have found no such wonderful secret. Nor do I expect to find
it, nor do I expect that anyone else will ever find it. It is
undiscovered. When you first began to gather my drift, perhaps
there was a resurrection of hope in your breast. Perhaps you said
to yourself, ‚ÄúThis man will show me an easy, unfatiguing way of
doing what I have so long in vain wished to do.‚Äù Alas, no! The
fact is that there is no easy way, no royal road. The path to
Mecca is extremely hard and stony, and the worst of it is that
you never quite get there after all.
The most important preliminary to the task of arranging one‚Äôs
life so that one may live fully and comfortably within one‚Äôs
daily budget of twenty-four hours is the calm realisation of the
extreme difficulty of the task, of the sacrifices and the endless
effort which it demands. I cannot too strongly insist on this.
5 - From Good Work (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/l2heh6ul47x6qvag/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL3dNeHdr
) by Paul Millerd

Good work doesn‚Äôt usually happen on a factory schedule and often
has a natural seasonality. But when you stop doing it, good work
seduces you back. It is something you must do. Once you discover
your good work, take it seriously and protect it, as it can be
one of the most powerful ways to show up in the world,
contribute, and feel useful.
Now to the book recommendations.

These were the most recommended, along with some of my own notes.

* ‚ÄãThe Kingkiller Chronicles Series (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/m2h7h6u39z4m27il/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL3Qyelo=
) by Patrick Rothfuss - Recommended by 9 people. I read books 1+2
back in like 2018, and have been waiting patiently (like the rest
of the fanbase) for book 3 for what seems like forever. I‚Äôd
actually kinda recommend you not start this series until the
third book comes out though‚Ä¶
* ‚ÄãEragon (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/dphehmueknp8d7fl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL2VyYWdvbg==
) by Christopher Paolini - Recommended by 4 people. Banger series
that I remember reading way back when I was a teenager. I haven‚Äôt
read the latest installation Murtagh just yet though, so that‚Äôll
be soon on my reading list :)
* ‚ÄãThrone Of Glass (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/e0hph0u7eorqmkf7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL1U0alA=
) series by Sarah J. Maas - Recommended by 4 people. I bought the
set in paperback a few years ago, thinking ‚Äúooh these look really
pretty‚Äù but never actually read any of them. Given the glowing
recommendations, guess it‚Äôll have to be the next series I read.
* ‚ÄãThe Lord of the Rings (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/7qh7h2u985nwdoc9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL1BrUGlnUmc=
) by JRR Tolkien - Recommended by 4 people. This is one of those
series where I‚Äôm like: ‚Äúyep there‚Äôs no excuse for why I haven‚Äôt
read this yet‚Äù. I tried Fellowship a bunch of times over the
years, but kept getting stuck on the Tom Bombadil stuff. Then I
listened to some of the audiobook and got beyond that point, but
fell off around Rivendell. Might be time to resume.

Then we had a few different series that were recommended by 3
people each:

* Wheel of Time by Robert Jordan (with the final 3 books written
by Brandon Sanderson after Robert Jordan‚Äôs death) - I read this
around 2018-2020 and would definitely recommend. It gets super
slow about halfway through the series, but it‚Äôs totally worth
pushing through the pain of those middle books to get to the
final few.
* ‚ÄãBeartown (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/owhkhwuwndqgxwbq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL3k5Z1l4VGc=
) by Frederick Backman - never heard of this, will add to the
list.
* ‚ÄãHunger Games (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/z2hgh7ue7xlp5piz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL09kNE5VZw==
) by Suzanne Collins - obviously incredible, loved the original
trilogy when I was in school, and loved the first prequel a few
years ago, and currently listening to Sunrise on the Reaping on
Audible
* ‚ÄãGentlemen Bastard Series (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/p8hehqu4doqgrxur/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL2R5YXlhdzQ=
) by Scott Lynch - I‚Äôve heard this recommended over the years but
never tried it, the name always sort-of put me off, making me
think: ‚Äúoh it doesn‚Äôt sound like a ‚Äòserious‚Äô series‚Äù but given
the recommendations from y‚Äôall, guess it‚Äôll have to go on the
list.
* ‚ÄãThe Poppy War (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92u972n8rdtnh6lzegwh5iz5d6d33cw/x0hph3uez0q9kxtg/aHR0cHM6Ly9nZW5pLnVzL3lJb0E=
) by R.F. Kuang - Never heard of it, will add to the list.

Big thank you to everyone who replied to last week‚Äôs email with
book recommendations :)

And apologies for no real ‚Äúcontent‚Äù from me this week - if you‚Äôve
reached this point in the email, I hope you got enough value from
the quotes + book recommendations that it‚Äôs been worth your
while. (And just an fyi, some of the links above are affiliate
links).

Have a great week!

Ali xx

Subject: üé® How to 10x your creativity
Body Text:
Hey friends,

üéâ Couple of quick things before we get started, especially if you're a current/aspiring creator:

1. If you've ever thought about starting a YouTube channel, or if you've got an existing one that you'd like to grow into an enjoyable, profitable, sustainable business, click here (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VVBfZK8nskKLW7GHn0v24hnRBW7swsJQ5nGhXXN4WpFgv3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3m6VCW_tb1ZmMrRN3Vz0jP236kzW78xF8B7kbYtDW5JtqXy37FcpDW7zggGB69T5HQW5JgRHF8RcrjkW1J9QcB6R4Fs6N7rfl0-Ck_KPW7BvcVj2f_WS-W6C9sp88qqfTpW216psS5_shjzW9lN0dK5BmyXzN51t30yHZ_X4W7RLP621ypyR0W5LRmY4858T_lW74ksd_2K4dNvW86YlRr1SDKMWW1Kmfbp96WrVzN85hMH88M-BkW4-l0KN7fksw2W6KXfZD6Yfbs7VsJLFV1PKtvYW3GBk-z7QmBRzW4fqc0Z26-Yz7f5s8f3P04 ) to join our Black Friday Waitlist (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VVBfZK8nskKLW7GHn0v24hnRBW7swsJQ5nGhXXN4WpFgv3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3m6VCW_tb1ZmMrRN3Vz0jP236kzW78xF8B7kbYtDW5JtqXy37FcpDW7zggGB69T5HQW5JgRHF8RcrjkW1J9QcB6R4Fs6N7rfl0-Ck_KPW7BvcVj2f_WS-W6C9sp88qqfTpW216psS5_shjzW9lN0dK5BmyXzN51t30yHZ_X4W7RLP621ypyR0W5LRmY4858T_lW74ksd_2K4dNvW86YlRr1SDKMWW1Kmfbp96WrVzN85hMH88M-BkW4-l0KN7fksw2W6KXfZD6Yfbs7VsJLFV1PKtvYW3GBk-z7QmBRzW4fqc0Z26-Yz7f5s8f3P04 ) . You'll be the first to get notified when when the biggest deal of the year for the Part-Time YouTube Academy course goes on sale ($675 instead of $995).

2. You may also want to check out The Publish Press, a free newsletter by OG YouTubers Colin and Samir breaking down the business of creators three times a week. If you fancy joining over 130,000 creators getting the latest news, sign up here (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VVBfZK8nskKLW7GHn0v24hnRBW7swsJQ5nGhXXN4WpFgb3pyd0W6N1vHY6lZ3nxW4CTHgc113mXJW1DfT0Q87kk8lW8Dt_wj2z5M24W1Vm5JX4MwTX4N4bbJZwjxTfpW1F-08z1TrhlZW4qVKDK6QZ3V2W3zzHmD556XLQW7T7z4J1NSmWfW8dKGRS918sVnV9zqtx84wMZlW94shB49drlQbVnc4Sv1sKrX0W5lfq6r5gn-5kW4SNdhW7PKB0fVNyQdt6zzm-tW25gZBN4CVllhW9k8v-h5wkf6sVtznRc2w4-bZW47RM9N6-t-ZRW501M-J5-bRC1W7X5Lbq2BZpgNf5z70k204 ) .

Anyway, let's talk about something I often get questions about - creativity. I had a minor epiphany about that recently that I'd love to share with you. Here's the story - this week, we published a YouTube video where I showed how I transformed my tiny room in Hong Kong into a glamorous studio (watch here (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VVBfZK8nskKLW7GHn0v24hnRBW7swsJQ5nGhXXN4WpFgv3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3mkVm7ytl4tlt6PVtHbKQ8RNgq5W51YkX_3PLB3sVML47X5NZ4ldW2fG0nP8C04XKW3c3wxn9lwHCVW8_rWsZ4J86gyN2jL5D2kM0SHW3v64LV3DncylW8tNwSn2BYjDSN9cMltQB8sDqV1mkxQ6kc-7pW3Z_ldq87Qw-4W75hZg916FQnWW8jv46j64j6B6W5ZWLXF2kYDRVW6282Pj5PSkFlW3xN0Gt5PSQcDW11bKbv6WRdgtW823Vjd6hQjVwW4MW5GF1CqPyFN5zwkPBhPRp7W4H3vKx10y52YW6w-2Zc7D6XLCf68-lz404 ) if you fancy üòâ).

At the start of the video, there was a transition shot where I snapped my fingers and the entire studio setup changed. It might just be one of my favorite things I've done in years.

The idea wasn't entirely "original". I first saw something similar in a Peter McKinnon video (https://djX7c204.eu1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/5H+113/djX7c204/VVBfZK8nskKLW7GHn0v24hnRBW7swsJQ5nGhXXN4WpFgv3pyd0W7lCdLW6lZ3mdW1pMGSG5TV7y7W8cdvmR4NQ-2YW3lLrf26cfDFsW5DQjnv7wV9S2VNVcT_7VBMwcV8XMyK36d8J3W8Wms_c1hfQ_VW5fjlJT2mrXb4W7PLDVZ3_d92bMF_WkVP6XyMW56z71N4hFBK2W6wD8mc1H9sRgW7ksTXK59HwjzW8k-g-F7Th5YwW8k1chs6FDjCmW8X5-lr24FMl1W6SXv8y8MyGBYW7KnLzR5bBS_qW60HtbB7XqdgYW6L3XC05XJ0SlW6pKFfd3yjsYBW4cCD1x2YnX8tW7rQPK288pQTPW4kWXBx3fjVYvf6NZKpF04 ) 7 years ago, where he used a finger-snap transition to show how to transform a terrible lighting situation into something amazing for less than $50.

Then about 4 years ago, I came across a tutorial about snap transitions on a random YouTube video. The real magic, I learned, was in the audio - you keep the echo of the snap going while the visual changes. That makes it feel way more realistic than just doing a straight cut.

I guess my subconscious mind stored these two events, from 7 and 4 years ago, to the point where when I was setting up my new studio, I thought "omg this is finally my chance to copy that snap transition". After filming and editing the opening, I excitedly showed a few friends, some of whom commented along the lines of "wow that's so creative".

That got me thinking - I never used to consider myself a creative person, because I felt I wasn't very original. But there's that quote from Steve Jobs: "Creativity is just connecting things".

The first bit of that quote is the "connecting" part. What looked like others to be "creative" in this case, was me connecting two YouTube videos I watched years ago, and applying it to my new living situation.

But the second bit of the quote is the "things" part. To connect things, you need to have things to connect. It sounds obvious, but I often speak to aspiring YouTubers who don't spend much time watching YouTube videos. Or increasingly to aspiring writers, who don't spend much time reading.

I've found that it's always worth "consuming" (urgh I hate that word) the "content" (I hate that word too) within the field you're creating in. I suspect Christopher Nolan probably spends a good chunk of time watching movies, for inspiration.

But of course, it's also good to consume content (urgh) outside of your own field. In every biography I've read, or every interview I've watched from any successful visionary creator or entrepreneur, they always have a bunch of eclectic interests outside of the field they work in. And they always credit those interests with a lot of their best ideas.

As a creator, you never really know which piece of content is going to be useful later. That tutorial you watch today might combine with a book you read next month to create something entirely new. It's all just background processing until something clicks.

In our Part-Time YouTuber Academy Q&As, students are often impressed when I can reference specific thumbnails or video styles from months ago. It's not because I have superhuman memory - it's just what happens when you enjoy the craft you‚Äôre doing, and enjoy seeing what others have created within it.

This is where the magic happens. That snap transition in the video is a combination of:

- A lighting technique from 6 years ago
- An audio trick from 4 years ago
- Various other bits and pieces I've picked up along the way

So here's what I'm thinking this week - if you're trying to make it as a creator, consuming content isn't just fun, it's part of the job. But don't just stick to your niche. Watch different types of content, read books, watch movies. Sometimes the best ideas come from unexpected places.

Have a great week!

Ali xx

Subject: ‚ÄúHey, did you mean to send me $5,000?‚Äù
Body Text:
‚ÄúCha-ching‚Äù

$5,000 hit my PayPal account.

‚ÄúThis has to be a typo‚Ä¶.‚Äù I thought to myself.

So I messaged him.

‚ÄúHey, did you mean to send me $5,000?‚Äù

His response:

‚ÄúYeah, is that enough?‚Äù

And just like that, ghostwriting completely changed my life
trajectory‚Ä¶

Hey - Dickie here!

This is the story of how I made my first $5,000 as a ghostwriter
and why I believe it‚Äôs the best career decision anyone interested
in writing or entrepreneurship can possibly make.

Here‚Äôs the story:

*****************************************************************
It was October, 10th, 2020 and I was working a full-time job on
Wall Street as a hedge fund trader.
*****************************************************************

But deep in my heart, I knew this wasn‚Äôt the career path I wanted
to take forever:

* The commuting
* The bureaucracy
* The 14-hour days & New York City corporate rat race

I struggled to wake up with any sort of excitement.

Hungry for a change, I decided 9 months earlier to start writing
on the internet.

I didn‚Äôt have any real goal or any clue what I was getting myself
into, but I figured putting ideas out there would lead to new
potential opportunities outside of Wall Street.

Spoiler alert: I was right.

9 months in, after 30+ blog posts and hundreds of hours slaving
over a hot keyboard, I finally started to see a little bit of
traction.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

I had just finished writing 30 Twitter threads in 30 days‚Äîmostly
curating the insights I was listening to from podcast episodes.
Looking back, this was sort of like ‚Äúfree Ghostwriting.‚Äù I would
inhale the rough, spoken ideas people would talk about on
podcasts.

Then, I would write up my takeaways into actionable Twitter
threads.

And the additional time it took me to write these had massive
upside and very little downside.

* Worst case: I better understood the concepts (because I wrote
them down and put them into my own words).
* Best case: The creator whose insights I curated would share the
thread & reach out to thank me for putting it together (which is
exactly what happened).

Truly a win-win.

***********************************
Then I got a serendipitous cold DM.
***********************************

After my 30th thread, I got a private message from someone asking
if I would be willing to do a curation thread based on their
insights.

‚Äã
I was floored. And clearly, I was onto something.

It just so happened I was listening to a podcast with them as a
guest that morning.

And that podcast sent me down the rabbit hole of all of their
work. Dozens of articles, keynote speeches, interviews, and
videos were spread across the internet, each of them filled with
golden nuggets but without any one place to find all of them.

And that‚Äôs exactly what this person wanted help with.

My job was to:

* Scour the internet to find all of that content
* Closely study it
* And organize it in a way that could serve as a rough outline
for a book

So when they asked if I was interested, of course I said yes! I
was planning on doing this work anyway, and now I could get paid
for it?

Count me in.

*******************************************
An awkward offer: ‚ÄúHow much do you charge?‚Äù
*******************************************

Now, when I agreed, they asked me how much I would charge them.

‚Äã
Uh-oh.

* I had no clue what to say.
* I had never made a single dollar on the internet.
* My gut said something like $250 (which would have been an
absolute home run).

If I could get 4 clients per month at $250, I would have a
$1,000/month side hustle income stream to supplement what I was
making at my full-time job.

But unlike my W2, this gig was something under my full control:

* My time
* My skills
* My effort
* My intensity

Its success depended purely on me (a feeling of ownership I
desperately craved). The lure of those first sweet digital
dollars was stronger than the scent of burning incense.

Luckily, I did not ask for $250.

In fact, I didn‚Äôt ask for any money.

Why?

Because I was terrified that if I asked for it, they might say
no.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

So instead, I said:

‚ÄúTo be honest, I have no clue what to charge. This would be my
first time charging for something like this. So how about I do
the project and then at the end, you can pay me however much
value it provided to you.‚Äù

They agreed and I immediately dived in.

************************************
I got to work to delight the client.
************************************

For the next 7 days, I immersed myself in their worldview.

Barely a second went by when I wasn‚Äôt consuming every article,
interview, and keynote I could find. And slowly but surely,
stories, patterns, and frameworks started to emerge. I bounced
back and forth between long walks listening to podcasts and
focused hours at my computer distilling my findings.

‚ÄúAm I really getting paid to do this?‚Äù

Yes indeed‚Äîand I was hooked on the idea of doing it forever.

7 days later, the project was finished‚Äîand it was a masterpiece.

* I organized all of their content into a database with distilled
insights from each of them.
* I created a rough outline for a book that would be the perfect
mix of storytelling, practical life advice, and actionable career
advice.
* I created a list of 50+ potential pieces of social content they
could create with outlines for each (since they were looking to
start sharing more on Twitter).
* And I shared a personal story about which frameworks were most
impactful to me, since I was quite literally the ideal reader for
the book they wanted to write.

I zipped it up into a polished Google Doc and sent it over.

Their immediate response:

‚Äã
‚ÄúThis is sooooooo good! Super helpful. I‚Äôve had a bunch of book
ideas in the past but this one is really on point. Thanks for
doing this. It‚Äôs going to take me a while to process it all
(which is a good thing). Glad we did this! Where can I send the
payment?‚Äù

Success!

******************
‚ÄúDoes Venmo work?‚Äù
******************

Venmo was the only way I knew how to accept money.

Again with no mention of how much to send. Since I only expected
a few hundred dollars of payment, I figured it could just sit in
my Venmo account balance and pay for future beers on the weekend
or something like that.

But the next morning, I got an email from their assistant saying:
‚ÄúThey are unable to send a Venmo with the amount requested‚Äîwould
you accept PayPal or a check?‚Äù

‚Äã
Woah‚Ä¶ I knew my Venmo limit was $1,000. They were going to send
me more than that?

Wild.

I snapped over to my computer, quickly set up a PayPal account,
and sent over the info.

****************************************
$5,000 (and $1,000,000 in realizations).
****************************************

A few moments later, there it was.

$5,000.

Five thousand dollars for work I was going to do for free anyway.
And just like that, my brain was completely broken‚Äîand my life
trajectory forever changed. Since I did a good job on this
project, they started to refer me to their friends for similar
work. I spent early morning and late evenings writing and
(begrudgingly) stared at charts and numbers for my Wall Street
job during the day.

‚Äã

Here I was, a 24-year-old working on Wall Street without any real
writing or business experience getting paid $5,000 to write for
clients.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

And this led to a few realizations about the world of
Ghostwriting:

* Ghostwriting was basically me getting paid to write & learn,
something I would have done for free anyway.
‚Äã
* Ghostwriting allowed me to charge far more than my time was
worth because I was providing value to people whose time was
worth much more than mine.
‚Äã
* Ghostwriting was a potential bridge from corporate prison into
a fully entrepreneurial life, providing me with the income & time
freedom to eventually spin something up on my own.

These realizations were worth millions to me on their own‚Äîwithout
the added kicker of getting paid.

*****************************************************************
Ghostwriting unlocked a completely new (and lucrative) network
for me.
*****************************************************************

Before I knew it, I was meeting and talking to people I had
looked up to for years. I was exposed to new business
opportunities, communities, and mentorship.

And most importantly?

My ghostwriting led to a connection with Nicolas Cole, which led
to Ship 30, which led to me escaping the Wall Street rat race I
sought to escape when this whole writing thing started.

And so I write this at 5:37 AM from my apartment.

* My dream production studio sits downstairs.
* I‚Äôm working on multiple businesses that pull me out of bed with
excitement each morning.
* And I get to do all of this on my own time, with no commute,
with a team I love working with, and without ever setting an
alarm clock.

I can confidently say I live a life today I dreamed about living
3 years ago.

None of this would have been possible had I not (accidentally)
ventured into the world of Ghostwriting.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Which is why I firmly believe becoming a Premium Ghostwriter is
the best career decision anyone interested in writing or
entrepreneurship can possibly make.

* If you‚Äôre looking to get paid to learn
* If you‚Äôre looking for a career with time & location freedom
* If you‚Äôre looking for the most ‚Äúplug and play‚Äù solopreneurship
opportunity on the internet

Then I highly recommend becoming a Premium Ghostwriter.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
‚ÄãClick here to take the next step in your ghostwriting journey
(and finally escape your soul-sucking 9-5). (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/0vu25776l2b9ho4g6zmulhv594855fn/p8hz8d5vhquzn3ng5ofr/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cucHJlbWl1bWdob3N0d3JpdGluZ2FjYWRlbXkuY29tL2tpY2tzdGFydGVyLWNhbGw_ZWw9TndfT2N0MjMmaGU9YWljb2FjaGluZzIwMjUlNDBnbWFpbC5jb20=
)‚Äã
-----------------------------------------------------------------

I can‚Äôt wait to see where this will take you!

‚ÄîDickie

Co-founder, Premium Ghostwriting Academy.

PS‚Ä¶ Ghostwriting hasn‚Äôt just changed my life‚Äîit‚Äôs changing lives
inside PGA as you read this email.

Take Derek here (who might be an outlier, but is a fantastic
example of the power of ghostwriting).

He landed a $10k client after asking for $3,600 per month for
LinkedIn ghostwriting‚Äîthe most he‚Äôs ever charged.

Premium Ghostwriting is the cheat code to getting paid more and
working with leaders in your industry.

‚ÄãClick here to take the next step to changing your life as a
ghostwriter. (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/0vu25776l2b9ho4g6zmulhv594855fn/g3h5zg8kuwu34d46owt3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cucHJlbWl1bWdob3N0d3JpdGluZ2FjYWRlbXkuY29tL2tpY2tzdGFydGVyLWNhbGw_ZWw9TndfT2N0MjMmaGU9YWljb2FjaGluZzIwMjUlNDBnbWFpbC5jb20=
)‚Äã

‚Äã

# _**Books**_

1. **Instagram Power by Jason Miles**: Strategies for leveraging Instagram to enhance brand visibility and audience engagement.

2. **InstaBrain by Sarah Weise**: New marketing strategies aimed at effectively engaging Generation Z on Instagram.

3. **Contagious by Jonah Berger**: Explores why certain content becomes popular, focusing on six key principles.

4. **Crushing It! by Gary Vaynerchuk**: Provides a roadmap for leveraging social media and personal branding.

5. **Epic Content Marketing by Joe Pulizzi**: Shows how creating engaging content is the new future of advertising.

6. **Building A StoryBrand by Donald Miller**: Outlines a framework for clarifying brand messaging to enhance marketing effectiveness.

7. **Superfans by Pat Flynn**: A guide to the strategies individuals and organizations can use to drive significant change.

8. **Atomic Habits by James Clear**: Teaches how small, consistent habits can lead to remarkable results. Can be applied to content creation too because you need to be consistent to create an impact. 

9. **Jab, Jab, Jab, Right Hook by Gary Vaynerchuk**: Teaches how to create effective social media content by providing value before making sales offers.

10. **Instagram Secrets by Jeremy McGilvrey**: Reveals strategies for growing your Instagram following and monetizing your influence.

reason. These standout programs from top universities and institutions
consistently deliver on what matters most: real-world skills, career impact, and
learner success.

Whether you're looking to boost your r√©sum√©, break into a new field, or gain
recognition in your current role, these flexible, online programs are built to
support your goals ‚Äî on your schedule, and at a price that works for you. Find
your certificate
[https://click.sfmc.edx.org/?qs=dfbfc1909b64ac11c9971a2c25970b3c48edcd80d17c6a64cf11654cc7b3e8a677fe262fa7bf64a83960faa16ce673994f1d26681b07d0b4b5791ecb1a65eb5a]

computer science certificates, designed to help you build practical skills in
programming, systems, and software development. IBM
[https://corp-mktg.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/creative-production/edX-UMT/IBM+(300X152).jpeg]

learning, large language model types, and neural networks.

solve programming problems efficiently.

from a top university can help you build the skills to make smarter decisions,
drive growth, and thrive in any industry. Wharton
[https://corp-mktg.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/creative-production/edX-UMT/Wharton+(300x152).jpg]

of your business.

Subject: Goals 9/16
Body Text:
Win either the October 5, November 2 and Dec 7th, or January 4th Powerball.
Between 150 and 550 million.

Win the housing lottery in a clean neighborhood with a whole foods nearby.

Be in my own home, a townhouse on 5th Avenue by April 14th, 2025.

Complete my wardrobe by May 2025
Have a home in one of those neighborhoods I see when I am moving around the
city.

Build my self care shelves by January 7th.

Build fully decked out YouTube Studio by Decemver 14th.

Decorate Sunnyside by the Saturday before Thanksgiving.

Subject: How to make more üí∞ as a ghostwriter
Body Text:
The one core truth I wish more new (and even experienced)
ghostwriters would internalize:

The best ghostwriters in the world practice on themselves.

* There is a reason why Will Smith hired Mark Manson, the
best-selling author of The Subtle Art of Not Giving a Fck*, to
write his memoir.
‚Äã
* There is a reason why Rick Rubin, M√∂tley Cr√ºe, Kevin Hart, and
a handful of other notable public figures hired Neil Strauss,
author of the best-selling ‚Äúpickup artist‚Äù memoir, The Game, to
write their books.
‚Äã
* There is a reason why venture capitalists don‚Äôt hire big fancy
New York City PR firms, but twenty-year-olds on Twitter with a
knack for going viral, to help them write their Threads.

And there is a reason why so many Silicon Valley founders and
C-level executives hired me, at 26 years old, to write opinion
articles on their behalf.

And the reason is:

********************
Pattern recognition.
********************

When a client hires a ghostwriter, they aren‚Äôt looking for
someone to manage or ‚Äútell them what to do.‚Äù

They don‚Äôt want to buy your ‚Äútime‚Äù or your ‚Äúeffort.‚Äù What they
want is your specialized knowledge‚Äîand its ability to accelerate
upside (helping them succeed faster) and mitigate downside
(making sure they don‚Äôt present themselves poorly).

Nicolas Cole üö¢-->

@Nicolascole77

Successful people monetize their mistakes more than their
insights. They know their "value" isn't in what they know how to
do, but what they know not to do and why. Others pay for access
to their pattern recognition of what went wrong. (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/8ghqh3ulmq9repal/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9OaWNvbGFzY29sZTc3L3N0YXR1cy8xNzM0OTA5MTQwNTA4NTI0Nzc4
)
5:12 AM ‚Ä¢ Dec 13, 2023

13
Retweets
119
Likes

Read 25 replies (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/8ghqh3ulmq9repal/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9OaWNvbGFzY29sZTc3L3N0YXR1cy8xNzM0OTA5MTQwNTA4NTI0Nzc4
)
‚Äã
Which means the key to unlocking bigger and bigger opportunities
for yourself as a ghostwriter is to specialize and build highly
valuable pattern recognition‚Äîas quickly as possible.

How?

By practicing on yourself.

I‚Äôm always amazed at how many people in the world want to get
paid to do things for others that they aren‚Äôt willing to do for
themselves.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Imagine a carpenter pitching you on building your house but
doesn‚Äôt take care of their own home.

Or imagine a hair stylist offering to cut your hair but has the
worst hair you‚Äôve ever seen.

These might seem like ridiculous examples, but there are millions
of marketing agencies that sell ‚Äúsocial media management‚Äù and yet
can‚Äôt build an audience of their own, and millions of freelance
writers that sell services like ‚Äúsales copywriting‚Äù but have
never sold a product in their life.

Not practicing on yourself, severely hinders your ability to
build highly valuable pattern recognition‚Äî which severely limits
the amount of opportunities you can unlock in your career.

*****************************
Ghostwriting is no different.
*****************************

A lot of writers think of ghostwriting as a completely new skill
set.

It isn‚Äôt a different kind of ‚Äúwriting.‚Äù Ghostwriting is just a
new word for ‚Äúwriting for yourself, for someone else.‚Äù

* If you want to ghostwrite opinion articles, you should know how
to write a really compelling opinion article for yourself.
‚Äã
* If you want to ghostwrite educational email courses, you should
know how to create educational email courses for yourself.
‚Äã
* If you want to ghostwrite Tweets, Threads, or LinkedIn posts,
you should know how to create these assets for yourself‚Äîtesting,
experimenting, and mastering these mediums.

The most valuable opportunities don‚Äôt flow to ‚Äúghostwriters.‚Äù

The most valuable opportunities flow to those who write (and
practice on themselves), AND who also ghostwrite.

Nicolas Cole üö¢-->

@Nicolascole77

I treat writing like an athlete:

‚Ä¢ Practice every day.
‚Ä¢ Prioritize sleep & hydration.
‚Ä¢ Seek out new mentors, teachers, etc.
‚Ä¢ Spend time around people who push me.
‚Ä¢ Don't read for enjoyment. Read to study the craft.
‚Ä¢ Find/create weird ways to practice my weaknesses. (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/vqh3hmupzegw2duw/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9OaWNvbGFzY29sZTc3L3N0YXR1cy8xODI2MjEyODE1MDQ2MDk5MTMy
)
4:0 AM ‚Ä¢ Aug 21, 2024

17
Retweets
281
Likes

Read 81 replies (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/vqh3hmupzegw2duw/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9OaWNvbGFzY29sZTc3L3N0YXR1cy8xODI2MjEyODE1MDQ2MDk5MTMy
)
‚Äã
This is an extremely important nuance for 4 key reasons.

*********************************************
Reason #1: The energy you bring to your work.
*********************************************

There is a giant energetic difference between working with
someone who treats writing as their ‚Äúday job‚Äù vs someone who
writes because they love it.

The former will almost always do the bare minimum (and only push
themselves when they realize their ‚Äújob‚Äù is at risk). And the
latter will almost always go above and beyond‚Äînot because they
are an overachiever, but because they can‚Äôt help but rack up more
hours of practice (and improve at an exponentially faster rate).
I experienced this firsthand building my ghostwriting agency.

All of the writers I hired who treated ghostwriting as their ‚Äúday
job‚Äù were nowhere near as effective as the employees who also
wrote for themselves, on their own time.

*****************************************************************
Reason #2: Clients will trust your opinion more when you speak
from personal experience.
*****************************************************************

Again, the highest-paying clients do not want to buy your ‚Äútime‚Äù
or your ‚Äúeffort.‚Äù

What they want to buy is your pattern recognition‚Äîand part of
that pattern recognition is assurance. When you make a
recommendation to a client and are able to say, ‚ÄúTrust me, I have
done this a thousand times for myself and I know it works.‚Äù

* There is no debate.
* There is no discussion.
* There is no doubt in the client‚Äôs mind about the right course
of action.

They can rest easy knowing they are in good hands.

*****************************************
Reason #3: The opportunities you attract.
*****************************************

The biggest-name, highest-paying clients would rather seek out a
well-known writer and try to convince them to be their
ghostwriter than interview ‚Äúa bunch of ghostwriters‚Äù and pick the
best one.

Which means, if you want to accelerate your career as a
ghostwriter quickly, one of the best (and easiest) things you can
do is build yourself as a writer, too. The fact that Mark Manson
doesn‚Äôt say anywhere that he is hirable as a ghostwriter, and yet
he was the one who got the opportunity to ghostwrite Will Smith‚Äôs
memoir, should tell you something.

Dickie Bush üö¢-->

@dickiebush

A quick & easy way to upskill as a ghostwriter:

Practice In Public.

‚Ä¢ Ghostwrite eBooks? Write eBooks for yourself.
‚Ä¢ Ghostwrite LI posts? Write LI posts for yourself.
‚Ä¢ Ghostwrite IG captions? Write IG captions for yourself.

Prove it works for you, first. (
https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/l2heh6u386rx5ksg/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9kaWNraWVidXNoL3N0YXR1cy8xODE3OTkwNjcxNDgwODM2Mzc0
)
11:28 AM ‚Ä¢ Jul 29, 2024

2

117
Likes

https://click.convertkit-mail.com/xmug633xvgf6hrmvxl8f5h29erlllsn/l2heh6u386rx5ksg/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9kaWNraWVidXNoL3N0YXR1cy8xODE3OTkwNjcxNDgwODM2Mzc0
)
‚Äã
Practicing on yourself is the single best way to demonstrate your
skill.

*******************************************************
Reason #4: You can charge more and more as you improve.
*******************************************************

The result of all the above, of course, is that you can charge
more.

I am just now (8+ years of ghostwriting later) starting to
experience this. When someone reaches out, asking if I am
available to be their ghostwriter, they contact me because of 3
specific reasons.

* They‚Äôve read one of my books.
* Or they‚Äôve taken one of my courses.
* Or they are subscribed to one of my newsletters.

And they want me to do what I do for myself, for them.

The discussion isn‚Äôt, ‚ÄúWe need a ghostwriter‚Äîhow much do you
charge?‚Äù The discussion is, ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre doing is what we want to
do‚Äîhow much money will it take?‚Äù

Having your own career as a writer gives you all of the leverage
and all of the pricing power.

So, if you want to be a crazy successful (and lucrative
ghostwriter), you have to internalize this truth:

You are not ghostwriting. You are writing (and practicing) for
yourself, for someone else.

That‚Äôs it!

Cole
