Subject: From Boom to Bundle: The Great Consolidation of Data Tools
Body Text:
View this post on the web at https://seattledataguy.substack.com/p/from-boom-to-bundle-the-great-consolidation

One of the defining challenges of working in the data industry is the sheer volume of tools and technologies available. Over the past decade, as interest in big data and data science surged, investment in data solutions followed. We went from venture capitalists (VCs) backing companies like Cloudera and Hortonworks to modern tools like dbt and Fivetran.
This rapid expansion has made the ecosystem more crowded every year. A great example is the MAD (Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, and Data) Landscape that Matt Turck [ https://substack.com/redirect/e9e18559-7210-46a2-a1d2-7f08d4c14479?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] and his team put out annually. Each iteration of this landscape is a testament to the growth and complexity of the space, where identifying a single logo among hundreds becomes difficult.
Lately, though, I‚Äôve been hearing more and more people in the data space talk about consolidation. There‚Äôs only so much room in the market: a limited number of customers, talent, and demand for these tools. And with the end of zero-interest rate policies (ZIRP), it‚Äôs getting hard to secure funding for future rounds.
On top of that, the new U.S. administration seems more open to mergers and acquisitions (M&A), which means we could see a wave of consolidation in the next couple of years.
I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if companies like Meta and Amazon started buying up some GenAI companies. It‚Äôs already happening in the startup world‚Äîjust look at the recent acquisitions of SDF Labs, Upsolver, Rivery, and Quary. If this is any indication of what‚Äôs to come, it looks like we‚Äôre off to a strong start this year.
In this article, we‚Äôll discuss these acquisitions, what they mean for the industry, and what other experts are saying about this growing trend.
What‚Äôs the Impact of Consolidation?
When companies merge, it‚Äôs easy to see both the good and bad outcomes. After all, some acquisitions are major wins‚Äîlike Instagram [ https://substack.com/redirect/592b9459-ff8a-49bc-8f80-09fc3896a512?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]‚Äîwhile others fade into obscurity, much like Mint [ https://substack.com/redirect/70096e42-21ed-469a-ba2f-0a155987d096?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
To dig into this, I wanted to share some insights from a data leader who preferred to stay anonymous. Once you hear their perspective, you‚Äôll understand why.
‚ÄúI have mixed emotions on the latest acquisitions. Tool consolidation makes sense, and it‚Äôs not unusual for a startup to get acquired by a large company. It's also much better than startups going out of business. So, I am happy for friends who work at these companies.
As a customer, I‚Äôm cautious. Looker is a great example of an acquisition that didn't work out so well for some customers. If you‚Äôre not on BigQuery, you‚Äôre stuck with no new features and very poor support. And when you ask for something, they aggressively push you to move to BigQuery.
For Uspolver <> Qlik, the first thought I had was "oh no." Qlik has never been on my list of tools to evaluate. And from what I‚Äôve heard from others, it's expensive and not all that great. They also already have Talend, and I believe they bought an EL company a while back. Will Upsolver thrive there? I am not so sure.‚Äù
Looker‚Äôs mention is an important one‚Äîit‚Äôs a tool that used to feel like a real competitor to Tableau. But now? Anecdotally, it seems to have lost some of its shine.
With all that in mind, let's dive into these recent acquisitions and break down what they might mean for the data space and its tools.
Cementing dbt vs. SQLMesh
It‚Äôs starting to feel like the data transform space is boiling down to a showdown between dbt [ https://substack.com/redirect/40006876-3cd3-44f2-a2e1-571779617970?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] vs. SQLMesh [ https://substack.com/redirect/745eb5e3-9bb8-47cc-b2a9-be897c517102?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]‚Äîat least for tools that focus on the ‚ÄúT‚Äù in ELT/ETLs [ https://substack.com/redirect/b7f48001-4bbf-4f07-9eba-979c11d29124?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. 
Sure, there are still plenty of ETL tools out there‚Äîlike Informatica and Matillion‚Äîthat developers can choose from. But when it comes to SQL first-based choices, then, you‚Äôre likely picking between dbt and SQLMesh.
And congrats to SQLMesh for making waves‚Äîapparently, they‚Äôve ruffled enough feathers to get banned from dbt‚Äôs conference!
To get some perspective, I reached out to several individuals who spend a lot of time in the data space for their initial thoughts on dbt‚Äôs purchase of SDF Labs [ https://substack.com/redirect/869abea3-e9e0-45fc-ae08-6a980a4f43cc?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
‚ÄúThis is a good move by dbt [ https://substack.com/redirect/e0b83f6d-d746-40cd-8211-4a36f504c846?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. I don‚Äôt know much about SDF, but it understands SQL and is much faster, which is something dbt lacks today. I suppose dbt wanted it to do more but didn't have the foundation to make it happen, hence the acquisition. I wonder why SDF folks didn't want to remain as competitors. 
One interesting comment I saw yesterday was that some of the new, awesome features being integrated into dbt might end up behind a paywall. That‚Äôs a valid concern. I like how SQLMesh offers most of its features as open source, and I think‚Äîor hope‚Äîthat dbt will follow that approach moving forward. 
In short, I'm excited to see what dbt will bring to the table in the coming years and how SQLMesh [ https://substack.com/redirect/9469dd2a-cdd5-4d44-995b-857957f63faa?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] will compete with them.‚Äù  - Yuki Kakegawa [ https://substack.com/redirect/21c06f71-928b-4a12-a69c-0035f8113f0e?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] - Independent Data Consultant at Orem Data
What's missing from dbt today?
Catching syntax and data type errors before sending the query to the warehouse (we're spending compute dollars just to find out a query doesn't actually run).
The ability to run and test models locally.
Linting and formatting. Usually, SQL Fluff is tacked on to dbt, but its performance is very slow, causing longer CI runs.
Column and Table name auto-complete in IDEs outside of dbt Cloud.
Faster compile times on large projects.
Where does dbt outshine SDF?
The ability to self-host or share dbt Docs: I web UI to navigate through lineage and documentation.
Out-of-the-box Unit Test.
Type 2 Slowly Changing Dimensions (dbt Snapshots).
Community
Jeff Skoldberg [ https://substack.com/redirect/0c078ebc-8835-48d6-907b-e20eed4bd0ec?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] - Principal Consultant, Data Architecture and Analytics Green Mountain Data Solutions, LLC
‚ÄúData engineering teams are continuing to consolidate around the use of SQL as their lingua franca, and I think it will be tough for anyone to go against that trend. dbt's acquisition of the SDF team is further proof, as they build out their SQL-centric capabilities for dbt users annoyed with Jinja and Python for templating.‚Äù- Ryan Wexler [ https://substack.com/redirect/bedf7c8a-e574-44e7-b631-b9aefbc8e3cc?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] Principal SignalFire
One point I‚Äôd like to make about the dbt and SDF Labs acquisition is that we‚Äôve now consolidated it to one of the two: dbt or SQLMesh when it comes to picking a SQL first transform layer. Again, there are other options, but the focus both have on being SQL focused and, more importantly, the fact that they make it easier to approach a multi-engine [ https://substack.com/redirect/8d3d59b7-8e1c-4e2a-8a87-2aa75b8283aa?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] data stack combined with the recent focus on Iceberg [ https://substack.com/redirect/0a7d521a-f087-45af-8426-a04678c3e8e8?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] is shaping up the data world to be less restrictive.
This competition is healthy, and I‚Äôm excited to see how each solution evolves for the user in 2025.
SeattleDataGuy‚Äôs Newsletter is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber.
Rivery And Upsolver - Everyone Wants Change Data Capture
Before the end of 2024, it was announced that Boomi had acquired Rivery [ https://substack.com/redirect/2d0cc570-df16-497d-a4ec-ab914a5f2724?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. I genuinely thought, wow, I have only ever seen Boomi once on another consultant's list of tools they use. In all fairness, this is likely due to the fact that Boomi is positioned more toward IPaas vs analytical data workflows. Also, I had no idea that Dell once owned Boomi, which was only recently purchased by Francisco Partners [ https://substack.com/redirect/db6251ac-0f4d-4775-be13-fa43ae641952?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] and TPG Capital [ https://substack.com/redirect/2511e0ca-fd9a-45ea-ab01-f2dafc85b2fe?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] in 2021.
Now, Upsolver has been bought out by Qlik [ https://substack.com/redirect/51915760-3465-49f5-a524-9fe0990b2e0e?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. While both tools share similarities‚Äîlike having an ingestion component, including CDC [ https://substack.com/redirect/e77ec112-47ea-4b22-a69e-58dbf9b38b04?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]‚Äîthere are some differences. Rivery has been heavily centered on data integration, transformation, and orchestration, whereas Upsolver had started branching into the managed Iceberg space.
Side note: If you‚Äôre looking for a tool to ingest data into your data warehouse or lakehouse, let me quickly plug Estuary [ https://substack.com/redirect/569a76da-31a9-4e2e-9fde-eb20f8a47205?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]‚Äîit‚Äôs a great option whether you‚Äôre loading data into Iceberg [ https://substack.com/redirect/b41a1e52-e72a-478a-a0c9-c01b7af5c667?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], Snowflake, or another platform.
So, what do other data experts think of these acquisitions?
Well, Lindsay Murphy [ https://substack.com/redirect/5f4993da-75c4-4dad-a79d-97b0546b6ee7?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], Director of Data at Hiive, provided her take on Qlik's acquisition. 
‚ÄúThe thing I'd say about Qlik is they‚Äôre a bit like Google‚Äîthey buy a bunch of companies, and then those products collect dust (e.g., Talend bought Stitch‚Ä¶ Qlik bought Talend‚Ä¶ Stitch hasn't had many new features in like 10 years).‚Äù
She also noted:
‚ÄúQlik has made 18 acquisitions [ https://substack.com/redirect/803c6bde-3971-4c83-9f82-cf4b99aaa81a?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] so far, and it seems like they average about one a year. These acquisitions in close succession might signal the start of "the great consolidation" of MDS tools people have been talking about for a few years now.‚Äù
That said, if Qlik can successfully integrate Upsolver‚Äîespecially with its Iceberg features‚Äîit could help Qlik remain competitive. After all, Qlik's been around since 1993, navigating decades in a turbulent industry. Not every acquisition they‚Äôve made has been a home run, but they‚Äôve managed to stay in the game, and I know more than one Qlik consultant who would vouch for their staying power. So although I do agree there is a good chance Upsolver could simply become another forgotten acquisition, it makes sense why Qlik purchased them. 
On the other hand, Boomi doesn‚Äôt have the same history of acquisitions‚Ä¶.Yet!
Prior to Rivery, they only acquired two other companies. It‚Äôs also nearly doubled in size in the last five years in terms of a number of employees and was foreshadowing this M&A since last year when its CEO stated ‚ÄúWe are in absolute predator mode,‚Äù when he was referencing the fact that:
Falling valuations precipitated by the shift of venture capital funding to generative AI, he added, ‚Äúcreates incredibly compelling acquisition opportunities. We‚Äôre going to be doing some M&A in the next couple of months.‚Äù -  [ https://substack.com/redirect/c00828fe-949e-4204-a46b-6f46df0cd6f5?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]Boomi CEO: ‚ÄòWe are in absolute predator mode‚Äô [ https://substack.com/redirect/c00828fe-949e-4204-a46b-6f46df0cd6f5?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
In the end, many of us were discussing the very frothy valuations of most data companies back in the early 2020s, and now, there will be a fair bit of haircuts to valuations and buying opportunities for companies who have the capital.
Where is the Rest of the Year Going?
As mentioned earlier, I believe we‚Äôll finally start to see more startups being acquired over the next year or two. Many of these companies received funding between 2018 and 2022, but since then, it‚Äôs been a matter of sink or swim. While some startups are doing fine, others would benefit from being acquired or merging to offer a fuller suite of features for their end-users.
Yuki shared another interesting thought on this:
‚ÄúI think there may be some changes in the BI realm. There are newer tools like Sigma, Evidence, Hashboard, Omni, etc. I could see one acquiring another to supplement a lack of functionality or user base. Perhaps even something like Snowflake acquiring Sigma to compete with Databricks's new BI offerings.‚Äù
The BI space has always been challenging. Despite the emergence of new tools, Tableau and Power BI continue to dominate the market, making it tough for others to gain significant traction.
I could also see companies like Fivetran making moves to acquire other data ingestion tools‚Äîor even going the route of building out their own all-in-one solution.
Now that I think about it, perhaps Fivetran might look into buying out SQLMesh. After all, they are already using SQLMesh as their transform layer according to the customer list on SQLMesh‚Äôs website.
This kind of acquisition would not only help Fivetran create a more end-to-end offering but also improve its stickiness in the market. As Snowflake's [ https://substack.com/redirect/144b4361-8be5-47e2-8de8-6427382c73c3?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] direct integrations start eating into Fivetran‚Äôs ingestion market share, expanding their capabilities might be a smart play to stay competitive.
Closing Thoughts
As Lindsay pointed out, these recent acquisitions feel like the early signals of a larger consolidation trend. What I‚Äôve learned, though, is that these cycles take years to fully play out‚Äînot just a single year. Many of us started discussing this back in late 2023 or early 2024, and it‚Äôs clear we‚Äôre only at the beginning.
Here‚Äôs why I believe consolidation is ramping up:
Clients are increasingly asking for bundled solutions that simplify their tech stack.
VCs are no longer looking to fund every data solution under the sun. There are far fewer data infrastructure companies getting $50 million funding rounds without clear traction, though they still happen occasionally [ https://substack.com/redirect/b1d956f5-f8be-46cc-b4ef-921c8899bde1?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
The political climate around mergers is shifting. Larger companies like Google, Facebook, and Amazon may now have more freedom to acquire companies without the fear of regulatory pushback from leaders like Lina Khan [ https://substack.com/redirect/82bab04b-a677-4b09-8824-8fcb970228d1?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
That said, consolidation isn‚Äôt all sunshine and rainbows. While it‚Äôs exciting to watch these acquisitions unfold, it‚Äôs also tough to think about the companies that won‚Äôt make it. Some will run out of funding, and there won‚Äôt always be a bigger company willing to buy them out. That part of the story is hard not to feel a little down about.
But I don‚Äôt want to end on too somber a note. I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts: Which companies do you think will merge next? What acquisitions would you like to see?
As always, thanks for reading!
Video Of The Week - Don't Lead A Data Team Before Watching This - 5 Lessons You Need To Know As A Head of Data
Join My Data Engineering And Data Science Discord
If you‚Äôre looking to talk more about data engineering, data science, breaking into your first job, and finding other like minded data specialists. Then you should join the Seattle Data Guy discord!
We are now over 8000 members!
Join My Technical Consultants Community
If you‚Äôre a data consultant or considering becoming one then you should join the Technical Freelancer Community! We have over 1500 members!
You‚Äôll find plenty of free resources you can access to expedite your journey as a technical consultant as well as be able to talk to other consultants about questions you may have!
Articles Worth Reading
There are thousands of new articles posted daily all over the web! I have spent a lot of time sifting through some of these articles as well as TechCrunch and companies tech blog and wanted to share some of my favorites!
Netflix Introducing Configurable Metaflow
A month ago at QConSF, we showcased how Netflix utilizes Metaflow to power a diverse set of ML and AI use cases [ https://substack.com/redirect/15ad0ba4-ad5d-47bb-9b11-b2c56d8e815a?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], managing thousands of unique Metaflow flows. This followed a previous blog [ https://substack.com/redirect/0ba170a4-548d-4d3e-83fb-13aa37164b7a?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] on the same topic. Many of these projects are under constant development by dedicated teams with their own business goals and development best practices, such as the system that supports our content decision makers [ https://substack.com/redirect/a6207661-f348-4a4f-88c9-de4f9ef0b30d?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], or the system that ranks which language subtitles are most valuable for a specific piece of content.
Read More Here [ https://substack.com/redirect/4c133d51-3dc2-4e31-980e-4a46a9c2a4e2?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
Holy Grails of Data: Self-Service, Single Truths, and the Role of AI
For decades, data teams have been chasing multiple ever-elusive Holy Grails. These end goals get talked about heavily, but it feels as if very few data teams have indeed seen them.
And if they have, it was always at some other job.
The data world has many of them. Some are real, some aren't, and many are used by marketing and sales teams to sell the dream. In fact, when I first came into the data world, Tableau was selling self-service analytics hard. Of course, being new to the world, it makes sense; if end-users can access their data, they'll ask you fewer questions, right?
Well‚Ä¶sort of.
Read More Here [ https://substack.com/redirect/eff1d17a-1418-4a7c-ac64-36818e228790?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
End Of Day 159
Thanks for checking out our community. We put out 3-4 Newsletters a week discussing data, tech, and start-ups.

From Name: SeattleDataGuy and Torsten Walbaum from SeattleDataGuy‚Äôs Newsletter
Reply-To: SeattleDataGuy and Torsten Walbaum from SeattleDataGuy‚Äôs Newsletter <reply+2lncni&51dsk7&&78cd13fbf6499bf10d9db837c448583ec0a50d48912625d291deb9d50e687ac8@mg1.substack.com>
Subject: From Average To Exceptional: 5 Skills To Help You Become The Data Expert Everyone Wants To Work With
Body Text:
View this post on the web at https://seattledataguy.substack.com/p/from-average-to-exceptional-5-skills

Hi, fellow future and current Data Leaders; Ben here üëã
Today's post is a guest post from Torsten Walbaum , a former manager at big tech companies and Director at Rippling. Torsten also writes the newsletter Operator's Handbook [ https://substack.com/redirect/f64a0326-7c24-4eb3-a9ee-f8d6fa2890cc?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] where he shares in-depth guides on analytics and operations topics.
Collaboration between business and data teams is hard. Torsten has been on both sides of the equation, giving him a unique perspective on what makes some data folks more impactful than others.
In this post, he's sharing 5 key skills that will help anyone in data stand out and work more effectively with their business stakeholders.
Now let‚Äôs jump into the article!
Intro
A data team‚Äôs central purpose is not to do data work, but to drive business value through data.
Over the last 10+ years working at companies like Uber, Meta and Rippling, I have been on both sides: I was a ‚Äústakeholder‚Äù‚Äîrunning business teams relying on data teams for support‚Äîand I was leading teams of analysts and data scientists working with the business.
The hard truth I‚Äôve come to realize: The value created by the data team is typically not equally distributed. Instead, a handful of stand-out individuals deliver most of the business impact.
Managers start to give all high-impact strategic projects to these individuals, and cross-functional stakeholders directly approach them instead of going through the official intake process.
As a result, these are the folks that get promoted quickly because they have broad support from business leaders in addition to their own managers.
So the question is: What do these people do differently? And how do you become one of them?
This post aims to shed light on what makes some people in data an order of magnitude more impactful. And more importantly, how you can apply these same behaviors on the job (as an IC, or by teaching your team).
To do that, we are going to cover 5 key skills and behaviors incl. detailed real-life examples for each one.
Skill #1: Always work backwards from the problem
Many data people think business teams just want someone who builds what they ask, reliably and quickly.
But over time, you‚Äôll realize that business stakeholders often don‚Äôt actually know what they need. They deeply understand the problem they‚Äôre facing, but they lack the technical training to translate that into data & analytics requirements.
It‚Äôs your job to understand the business problems behind stakeholder requests and find the best data and analytics solutions to solve them.
This is crucial if you want to be viewed as a strategic thought partner instead of just an (interchangeable) execution resource.
Let‚Äôs look at an example:
Imagine you work at Uber, and a stakeholder asks you for a real-time reliability dashboard to manage their markets. Now, you might be tempted to start brainstorming ways to build that real-time data pipeline.
But you should first dig deeper into the use case:
If you stop here, the request might actually seem reasonable. Supply and demand in Uber‚Äôs marketplace change in real time, so real-time information seems helpful for balancing it.
But real-time data [ https://substack.com/redirect/f7c7f3b0-83b8-48c4-b0a6-26c4f88470f0?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] can be expensive and hard to get, so you should get more context before you proceed. Once you ask for details on the process, you realize that things are easier than you thought:
So based on what you learned, a few hours of lag in the data won‚Äôt affect your stakeholder‚Äôs ability to run their daily process; they‚Äôll still have yesterday‚Äôs data available in the morning. No need to build a real-time dashboard.
I cannot stress this point enough. In the example above, if you had just built what the stakeholder asked, you would have over-engineered it.
But in many cases, you‚Äôll end up building the wrong thing because you don‚Äôt fully understand the business use case.
For example:
The data team [ https://substack.com/redirect/99fb0742-5614-485d-bce0-d6697a8ac68f?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] starts building an attribution model by looking at the available data and thinking about modeling techniques instead of checking what decisions the Marketing team will make with it
Data scientists and engineers start debating what features and data pipelines [ https://substack.com/redirect/91935d34-0922-4242-93bc-02658cceafb1?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] to engineer for a lead scoring model without understanding what kind of model output would be useful for the Sales team
In these cases, months of work can end up going to waste because your deliverable doesn‚Äôt address the business need.
Skill #2: Use frameworks to create clarity
One of the most painful experiences for any data person are ad-hoc investigations into metrics movements.
At Meta, we were doing a lot of these investigations even into seemingly small fluctuations. At a scale of billions of users, this can translate into a massive monetary impact.
The business was complex, so we had to pull in many different teams and stakeholders to get all relevant context. Unfortunately, with many cooks in the kitchen, investigations often end up sounding like this:
And so on.
The main problem here is that everyone is just guessing. Without a proper structure, there is no guarantee you‚Äôll find the root cause. And even if you do, you can‚Äôt replicate that success in the next investigation.
In this case, a simple issue tree (one of the most useful general purpose frameworks) can help bring structure into your investigation:
There isn‚Äôt a single correct way to decompose an issue. The important part is that:
You use a structure at all. That way, you can get everyone to think about the problem the same way and keep track of what you already investigated
Your structure is MECE [ https://substack.com/redirect/522ab332-c120-4a34-8755-d7d824678494?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] (Mutually Exclusive and Collectively Exhaustive). That means it covers all possible options, and none of the options overlap
With the structure in place, nothing can throw you off track.
A stakeholder brings up a new hypothesis? You can quickly check your issue tree and either add it to the right step of the investigation, or show them that you already ruled it out
Leadership asks you when you will have an answer? You can see how many branches in your tree you still need to check and give them an estimate
SeattleDataGuy‚Äôs Newsletter is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber.
Skill #3: Reduce complexity
Once you embrace the fact that all data work is ultimately supposed to drive business impact [ https://substack.com/redirect/5adba5b2-79fc-441e-888e-d0e3b069b6ba?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], you realize that anything that distracts or delays you from realizing that impact should be eliminated.
It can be tempting to want to highlight the complexity of our work [ https://substack.com/redirect/54b72d49-df6a-4021-8323-f604685cf58d?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. If nobody realizes how complicated this all is, how can we get credit for it?
But the reality is that people are either Simplifiers or Complicators. And Simplifiers will be rewarded for making people‚Äôs lives easier, while Complicators will be sidelined because people avoid working with them.
So, how do you become a Simplifier [ https://substack.com/redirect/0696353a-cfe4-4ab1-99d2-f096e591d4ef?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]?
Avoid technical jargon
Using technical jargon makes it difficult for business stakeholders to understand you.
It doesn‚Äôt matter whether you use the terms correctly; if the other person doesn‚Äôt know them, there is a chance they‚Äôll misunderstand you. And most people don‚Äôt want to show their lack of knowledge, so they likely won‚Äôt ask you to clarify.
So: Whenever possible, say what you want to say in plain English (and simple sentences).
Boil it down to the essentials
Your business stakeholders are busy. When they ask for a data tool or dashboard, it‚Äôs typically to make their lives easier and save them time.
If you respond by bombarding them with detailed analyses, difficult trade-off decisions etc., they‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre making it harder for them instead.
Here are a few things you can do:
Use simple visualizations
When you‚Äôre working on a system all day, it‚Äôs easy to forget how confusing it must seem to outsiders.
For example, in my last job, my team and I got asked to do growth and analytics work for an automated email system. From lead ingestion to enrichment and finally allocation to different email sequences, the system was complex ‚Äî and there was no visual overview of it.
This caused a lot of confusion. Different teams had different levels of understanding of what was going on, and there were a lot of misconceptions.
The first thing we did, before doing any ‚Äúactual‚Äù work, was create simple flow charts that showed the system end-to-end. For the first time, everyone had a shared understanding, and for months we kept getting unsolicited positive feedback from stakeholders.
Streamline choices
Sometimes, you need your business stakeholders to make decisions on how to move forward.
When you‚Äôre presenting them with a decision like that, don‚Äôt lay out all options and considerations in detail. That will just confuse and overwhelm them since they lack the necessary context.
Instead, do the legwork on your end to eliminate as many options as possible. Then, present the final decision with a focus on the business implications, not the technical details:
Skill #4: Communicate effectively
Even if you‚Äôre using simple language, communication between data and business teams is often challenging. But there are some simple tricks you can use to address these problems:
Communication best practice #1: Focus on the ‚Äúso what?‚Äù and use the pyramid principle
When you‚Äôre communicating with stakeholders, you shouldn‚Äôt focus on what you find interesting to share, but what the other person needs to hear.
To make sure you get your message across, you should lead with the takeaway (the ‚Äúso what?‚Äù of your message) and then add supporting arguments and data.
Besides making it easier for the other person to follow your thought process, you immediately seem more senior by adopting this executive communication style [ https://substack.com/redirect/30b6c402-7e6d-4a72-8f72-43fa14d97f95?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
Communication best practice #2: Keep stakeholders in the loop
Data teams often feel like a black hole to business partners. You throw a request in their direction, and then you don‚Äôt hear anything for weeks.
Business stakeholders are the ones that are ultimately on the hook for hitting goals and metrics targets. So if they are waiting for the data team to do an analysis or build a tool and they don‚Äôt have any visibility into the progress, they get anxious.
Are you actively working on the project?
Are you building the right thing?
Will it be done in time?
To address this, proactively send them regular brief status updates (e.g. via Slack):
There will be several immediate benefits:
Your stakeholders don‚Äôt have to constantly check in, making both your lives easier
People see that you‚Äôre ‚Äúon top of things‚Äù and will trust you with larger, more complex problems
You can use the check-ins to get feedback on early drafts of your work to make sure you‚Äôre going in the right direction
Skill #5: Be pragmatic and make things happen
Many data people tend to be sticklers for accuracy and best practices.
For example, let‚Äôs say the business needs an analysis to answer a critical question within a week.
Knowing a proper analysis would take a month, a mediocre data person would insist that the request is unreasonable and spend the week debating the timeline instead of delivering something. As a result, the business would have to move forward without any analytical guidance.
A great data person, on the other hand, will find a ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù workaround to unblock the effort. They'll highlight the caveats and have a plan for a more robust follow-up analysis (if needed).
Our job on the data team is to help find the least bad solution within the constraints of the business. This doesn‚Äôt mean that we should ship work that we know is flawed to the point of being unhelpful, or completely ignore the scalability of what we build.
But it means that instead of insisting on the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù solution, we have to be flexible and adjust to business realities. If you do, people will notice.
In one of my last jobs, I was in a calibration meeting. When it came to discussing a Senior Data Scientist and their ‚ÄúExceeds Expectations‚Äù rating, we didn‚Äôt need much time. Everyone knew him as someone who simply got stuff done.
A Senior VP literally said ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never heard him say ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs not possible‚Äô‚Äù, and that settled it ‚Äî the rating was approved.
Making things possible beats being ‚Äútechnically correct‚Äù every time.
TL;DR
Technical skills are important when working with data. But those that create outsized business impact, and become the data person everyone wants to work with, also stand out in other areas.
They always work backwards from the problem
Deeply understand the problem your business stakeholders are facing before diving into technical solutions
Then, once you understand the use case and requirements, help them identify the best solution
They use frameworks to create clarity
For example, during investigations, use a structured issue tree instead of chasing random hypotheses
They reduce complexity
Avoid technical jargon whenever possible
Use simple visualizations to get a shared understanding of the situation
Make decisions easy for your stakeholders
They communicate effectively
Lead with the takeaway, then add supporting arguments and data (AKA the ‚ÄúPyramid Principle‚Äù)
Proactively keep your stakeholders in the loop on your progress
They are pragmatic and make things happen
Instead of listing out all the difficulties of a project, focus on how you can make it work
Offering a compromise / ‚Äúleast bad‚Äù solution is better than blocking the entire work stream
As always, thanks for reading!

The Tension of Orthodoxy and Speed
By Joe Reis  
Doing things ‚Äúthe right way‚Äù means being thoughtful and intentional in data modeling. This brings us to orthodox and conventional data modeling approaches. There was once a process that nearly everyone followed - intentional conceptual and logical modeling, having a shared vocabulary, modeling the business, and translating these models into a physical data model. The relational model has been the mainstay for transactional data used in applications since the 1970s. In analytics, Kimball‚Äôs dimensional model is the most popular approach, with Data Vault also prevalent in some areas. All of these approaches have an established way of handling data. There‚Äôs a ‚Äúright way‚Äù to relationally or dimensionally model data. Each approach has a framework, a vocabulary, and a goal. Follow the convention, and you‚Äôll have a data model that‚Äôs understandable by many people, performant (most of the time), and with minimal defects and higher quality. The latter point is key since higher quality often leads to the ability to move faster, as discussed a few months ago in The Quality Paradox [ https://substack.com/redirect/7564c8de-7c9d-415a-9525-ffc8310cad32?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].

Subject: Want a lucrative solopreneur biz, fast?
Body Text:
Hey there!

Solopreneurship is all the rage right now.

But if you‚Äôre looking to start something of your own (so you can
escape your 9 to 5) which solopreneurship ‚Äúpath‚Äù should you
choose?

Most people go the digital products route:

* Building an audience on either X, LinkedIn, or Instagram
* Listening for signal on their ideas and the problems their
audience faces
* And then creating digital products to solve these problems (and
selling it to their audience)

And yes, this is one route you can take as a solopreneur.

But this takes TIME. It means you have to build an audience. It
means you have to go through tons of trial and error to get your
product right, your copywriting on point, and all the back-end
fulfilment systems humming.

There is another way.

Premium Ghostwriting let‚Äôs you practice all the skills you need
to become a hugely successful solopreneur, helps you monetize
fast, and sets the foundation to help you scale with digital
products later.

Nicolas Cole üö¢-->

@Nicolascole77

Writers:

Services or Digital Products?

If you're new & want to monetize fast, I recommend services.
Charging $1,000, $2,000, or even $5,000 for a project is
reasonable. So instead of needing 50 or 100 customers per month,
you need 1 or 2.

Higher-ticket, less volume. (

Premium Ghostwriting.

Premium Ghostwriting allows you to tap into a network of
influential people in your niche or industry‚Äîand is like pouring
gasoline on the fire of your career.

As a ghostwriter, I‚Äôve built a billion-dollar network:

* CEOs
* Crypto billionaires
* Silicon Valley founders
* New York Times best-selling authors

And tons more.

I have used the connections I made as a ghostwriter to create
lucrative opportunities for myself, even after I moved away from
running a ghostwriting agency.

*****************************************************************
Reason #2: It helps you understand positioning (for you and your
clients).
*****************************************************************

As a Premium Ghostwriter, you don‚Äôt just get paid to write.

You get paid to think. And one of the most lucrative ways to do
this is to advise other people how to position themselves in the
market and how to name and claim their own niche. Because the
vasty majority of people struggle with this (and it‚Äôs costing
them money as a result).

But if you‚Äôre able to do this for your clients (and use words to
communicate this to their customers), then you can charge a lot
of money for your services AND do it for yourself.

(For context, I charge $2,000 for a ‚ÄúPower Hour‚Äù for people to
talk through their positioning and niche questions.)

*****************************************************
Reason #3: It helps you understand marketing funnels.
*****************************************************

Premium Ghostwriters are business consultants disguised as
writers.

Here are just a few elements of a marketing funnel you can build
and write for your clients:

* Social ghostwriting
* Email nurture funnels
* Evergreen newsletters
* Landing and sales page copywriting

This is something I call the Organic Content Vortex‚Äîand it‚Äôs what
more and more people and businesses will need as they recognize
the importance of going digital.

If you understand how to create these, you become a
highly-valuable solopreneur‚Äîbecause you can charge to do this for
others, learn what works, and then build it for yourself.

If you can master these 3 skills, you‚Äôre set‚Ä¶ FOR LIFE.

It doesn‚Äôt matter what you go into after ghostwriting, if you

services to customers & clients, and deliver those services with
a white-glove experience, you‚Äôll always be able to make money for

Period.

These 3 skills is how you make friends at scale‚Äîand can help you
influence more than just your career.

Sales is Education.

Sales is making friends at scale‚Äîand I wish more ghostwriters

****************************************************************
Reason #5: It helps you gather data for future digital products.
****************************************************************

Finally, becoming a Premium Ghostwriter helps you gather data for
future digital products.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

* Step 1: Use Your Information Advantage. Ghostwrite in a niche
you already know something about, helping experts in that
industry so you learn more about the market and what people need
help with.
‚Äã
* Step 2: Gather data on the problems in your niche. What
problems do you solve as a service provider? How do you solve
them? Ghostwriting gives you quicker answers to these questions
over ‚Äúbuilding an audience‚Äù any day of the week.
‚Äã
* Step 3:Build a digital product to solve those problems. Now,
create a course, community, or digital product to help solve
these problems for this target audience. Now you have your first
digital product! And through your outreach and fulfilment, you
have a market to sell the digital product to (without building an
audience).

And, using everything you know about positioning, marketing
funnels, and premium service delivery and fulfillment, you‚Äôll be
able to start selling your digital product faster than if you
were second guessing yourself just building your audience.

That‚Äôs it!

Dickie & Cole

Co-Founders, Premium Ghostwriting Academy

Subject: Breaking Into Data: How to Land Your First Job in a Competitive Market
Body Text:
View this post on the web at https://seattledataguy.substack.com/p/breaking-into-data-how-to-land-your

If you‚Äôve been keeping up with the job market, you‚Äôve probably seen stories about roles receiving hundreds if not thousands of applications within a few days, leaving hiring managers overwhelmed.
So, how do you stand out in such a saturated market?
How do you land a job‚Äîlet alone your first role in the data world?
I remember facing those same questions and feeling pretty hopeless. I was only six months away from graduating, with no technical work experience beyond teaching kids to code, and had already sent out hundreds of resumes. I managed to land a single interview, but being my first technical interview, I didn‚Äôt do so hot.
I get how discouraging it can feel just hoping someone will notice your resume and give you a chance.
If you‚Äôre starting your job search or are about to finish school, I want to share some tactical tips and personal insights to help you break into the data industry [ https://substack.com/redirect/5df328a5-d14f-465a-ac09-8bd69591fd6b?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ].
SeattleDataGuy‚Äôs Newsletter is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber.
1) Don‚Äôt Get Distracted By Job Titles, Remote Jobs or By Companies
When I was job hunting the second time around, I didn‚Äôt even know ‚Äúdata engineer‚Äù was a job title. I searched job boards by skill sets instead‚Äîthings I knew I had done before, like automating workflows, using SQL [ https://substack.com/redirect/f3b5ec78-848c-4a08-b5da-49b826e26c23?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], and building tables in a data warehouse. [ https://substack.com/redirect/e37f7d2e-f601-4a71-998b-05e097437506?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
Job titles evolve.
What used to be called an ETL Developer might now be labeled Data Engineer [ https://substack.com/redirect/38e6723c-1410-4376-8d9b-5b0f58af1230?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] with more expectations. Roles morph, overlap, and get rebranded all the time. If you get too caught up in chasing a specific title, you could miss great opportunities that match your skills.
The same goes for companies. Like many in Seattle, I was laser-focused on landing a job in big tech, especially since, at the time, Amazon was basically spamming job boards. Every other job was at Amazon.
But here‚Äôs the thing‚Äîthere are plenty of options:
Startups
Smaller companies
Healthcare organizations
Local companies in general
To name a few.
These companies often have fewer applicants and equally challenging problems to solve. So, while applying for big tech jobs can be part of your plan (if that‚Äôs your goal), don‚Äôt limit yourself.
Your first job doesn‚Äôt have to be flashy with a salary in the 99th percentile right out of the gate‚Äîit just needs to be a place where you can grow and learn.
2) If You Fail To Prepare, You‚Äôd Better Prepare To Fail
‚ÄúWhat should I study for my interview in two days?"
I get messages like this all the time‚Äîwhether during live sessions or in my YouTube [ https://substack.com/redirect/75d049f9-70fb-4f1d-b13f-2abb460b0de3?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] comments. Honestly, it stresses me out for those frantically cramming. I can only hope they‚Äôre asking for last-minute topics, not just starting to prepare.
Technical interviews [ https://substack.com/redirect/66d57aec-602b-46a5-a173-df092323f1f1?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] are tough. They typically cover a mix of programming, SQL, system design, statistics, and more. The last thing you want is to panic-study a dozen topics. But it‚Äôs also easy to feel overwhelmed by everything you can review. Here‚Äôs how to focus your efforts effectively:
Create a study plan
If you‚Äôve got an interview, ask your recruiter for topics
Find a group to keep you accountable
Don‚Äôt wait until the last minute to study. While some interviews might dive into role-specific technologies, most data-related interviews will test your SQL skills and often include light programming challenges. Preparing in advance ensures you‚Äôre ready for these core topics and can focus on areas that matter most.
Remember, you‚Äôve worked hard to get this interview opportunity‚Äîit‚Äôd be a shame for you to lose it because you didn‚Äôt start preparing until the interview date was set.
If you‚Äôre looking for interview guides, here are a few you can use:
Data Engineer Interview Guide [ https://substack.com/redirect/f82c7c3d-3c20-4b45-a108-ea706c79cbc2?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
Data Science Interview Guide [ https://substack.com/redirect/6dbe554c-0482-4af4-a10f-18b53107e60e?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
3) Relationships And Referrals
As the world leans further into AI, genuine, in-person relationships are becoming more critical. Our inboxes are overflowing with spam emails from B2B SaaS salespeople, and the constant noise online can make meaningful connections feel rare. Because of this, reverting back to more personal, face-to-face relationships seems inevitable.
I've already had multiple hiring managers reach out to me for referrals after trying the traditional route of posting job listings. They received so many resumes that sorting through them all became challenging. Instead, they turned to their networks, seeking recommendations from people they trusted outside their companies.
So, how can you start building up your own network and professional relationships? Here‚Äôs where you should begin:
Attend Data Events in Your Area: Check platforms like Meet-up.com or ask industry peers about events they recommend. I‚Äôve made a lot of connections through going to different meet-ups and events. I would recommend you don‚Äôt go in with the mind set that the people you are talking to owe you a job. It often can feel transactional to the people on the other side. 
Reconnect With Classmates: The mistake most people make when it comes to networking [ https://substack.com/redirect/925a1628-b746-483d-b8ad-06e86d7ef0b2?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] is they only reach out when you need something. So be better! Stay in touch with classmates or past colleagues. Check in on them. Ask them how they are doing, grab coffee, and be genuine. 
Leverage LinkedIn: LinkedIn is more than a place to post about how you just landed a new job. It‚Äôs also a great place to connect with people. However, simply sending your resume to someone and expecting a job offer won‚Äôt get you far. In fact, you can probably find several posts on LinkedIn complaining about that kind of behavior. Instead, engage with posts, comment thoughtfully, and share your learning experiences. By being active and authentic, you‚Äôll make more meaningful connections that can open doors over time.
Participate in Online Communities: There are countless data communities where you can engage with peers and discuss tools like dbt [ https://substack.com/redirect/4dc6e768-3e9d-49f2-bf07-b2d80c2ef436?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], SQLMesh [ https://substack.com/redirect/3661b1f6-b7b0-4f3c-af9b-856d9b73dfac?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] or Airflow [ https://substack.com/redirect/02950b9a-616d-4a70-b974-31c778a6dff5?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], as well as broader topics in data engineering and data science. Join these groups, ask thoughtful questions, share your progress, and contribute where you can. Avoid lurking‚Äîgetting involved is how you‚Äôll build a reputation and professional relationships.
Once you start meeting people, here are a few steps to help solidify and grow those relationships.
Ask Thoughtful Questions: When connecting with new people, show genuine curiosity about their experiences and perspectives. If the only thing you care about is getting a job, it shows. People will likely be turned off.
Follow-Up After Initial Meetings: If you've attended an event or had a conversation, follow up with a brief email or LinkedIn message. Honestly, most people don‚Äôt do this. Maybe you get busy or are afraid of what they‚Äôd think.
Be Intentional About Networking: I find that many people only passively network. They go to an event and meet maybe 1-2 people. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, your goal shouldn‚Äôt be to try to talk to everyone. But networking requires effort. You need to try to talk to a more than just one person. So be active at events, talk to people, find out who is managing the event, get to know them, etc.
Say Yes to Opportunities: If someone invites you to an event or introduces you to a new connection, take the opportunity. Expanding your circle often starts with being open to new experiences.
4) Obscurity Is the Enemy
I swear, it feels like everyone needs to be a brand or influencer just to get noticed. Honestly, I don‚Äôt believe that‚Äôs true‚Äîbut I do agree with other writers(see Joe Reis  ) who say obscurity is the real enemy when it comes to advancing your career.
That doesn‚Äôt mean you have to pump out content constantly (though sharing what you‚Äôre working on can be a powerful way to build visibility). Instead, here are some effective ways to avoid staying obscure:
Engage online‚Äîjoin different Slack groups, get involved, and be helpful.
Contribute to open source.
Write content and share what you‚Äôre learning.
Go to events and contribute to conversations.
If you‚Äôre not consistently doing one or more of these things, you risk losing out to those who are. Personally, I focused on writing and attending events‚ÄîI wanted to get involved, learn, and grow.
Need a little extra motivation? Check out Never Eat Alone [ https://substack.com/redirect/3b8eeff8-ad9d-41f2-b746-6929323f8408?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. Yes, it‚Äôs a bit of a cheesy business self-help book, but it does help motivate you to step out of your comfort zone.
At the end of the day, if no one knows you exist and if you‚Äôre relying solely on job applications, you could be waiting a long time to land your next role. Visibility matters‚Äîstart taking steps to get noticed.
Before we dive into the more tactical side of interview prep, I‚Äôd also like to add a quick tip from my friend Abhishek Gupta [ https://substack.com/redirect/e534459a-6073-43b0-ba77-dc2770118f1b?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] who has landed jobs at Facebook, Lyft and Stripe.
I would say be able to showcase end-to-end projects [ https://substack.com/redirect/db222e9a-9be2-45c0-9295-835d2d656f9f?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]. They don‚Äôt have to be super polished, but if you can talk about how you got data from a source system, to a downstream table, transformed it using airflow, and built something preliminary using superset, then I think the person interviewing would get a lot more confidence.
5) Tactical Steps For Interview Prep
Let‚Äôs talk tactical steps‚Äîwhat can you do today, next week, and over the next few months to land a job? Start with the basics:
Make Sure the Basics Are in Order:
Resume [ https://substack.com/redirect/4f7c2672-4a45-4ffd-a426-014cd1d36135?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]: Tailor it for each job, keep it ATS-friendly, and focus on achievements rather than tasks. Have someone you trust review it for clarity and impact. Also, I will say using tools like ChatGPT can help you improve your verb [ https://substack.com/redirect/0e632877-08d1-4e79-97d5-13011be1f08a?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] choice and also point out where your bullets are weak.
Portfolio: If you don‚Äôt have projects, now is a great time to start putting them together. You don‚Äôt have to have a fancy portfolio website, but at least put together a Github project and show them off. 
LinkedIn Profile: If you are using LinkedIn to comment, post and engage, make sure you clearly show what your skill sets are. Share Github links, talk about past projects, have a buttoned up profile, etc. 
Track Your Progress: One of the biggest challenges during a job search is staying motivated. Often, the struggle comes from not keeping track of your efforts. I have had conversations with people who think put in a lot of effort but have only put out about 20-30 job applications and haven‚Äôt even gone out of there way to meet new people. I get it, it is a hard market, but you can‚Äôt expect jobs to just fall into your lap. So ask yourself, how many applications have you actually submitted? How many meet-ups have you attended? Keep track of:
Applications Sent
Meet-ups
People You Meet and Follow-Up With
Study and Prepare:
Create an Interview Checklist: Don‚Äôt study randomly‚Äîbuild a checklist [ https://substack.com/redirect/6dbe554c-0482-4af4-a10f-18b53107e60e?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] of topics, questions, and resources, marking them off as you go(like the ones provided above).
Mock Interviews: Practice both technical and behavioral questions to build confidence. The best way to do this would be to get a friend who is also technical to interview you. Colleges also often offer options here where you can go to the career center and have someone interview you.
Keep Yourself Accountable:
Set Weekly Goals: Define clear, achievable targets like ‚Äúapply to 10 jobs,‚Äù ‚Äúreach out to five people,‚Äù or ‚Äúattend one networking event.‚Äù Many job seekers say, ‚ÄúI am trying to find a job,‚Äù but without a structured plan, they often fall into the trap of sporadically sending out resumes without consistent effort.
Celebrate Small Wins: Recognize milestones along the way‚Äîgetting an interview, connecting with a key contact, moving past the first phone interview, or advancing to the technical round. Many people overlook these moments, but each step forward is progress worth acknowledging.
Final Thoughts
Landing a job‚Äîespecially your first‚Äîhas been tough for a while. I remember when I was trying to break into data, people struggled with similar issues.
Entry-level jobs required 2-3+ years of experience.
ATS filters rejected resumes before a human ever saw them.
The surge of interest in becoming a data scientist saturated the market.
Now, we‚Äôre also competing for remote jobs and facing the added challenge of LLMs churning out thousands of generic resumes. However, challenges will continue to exist and evolve. That doesn‚Äôt mean you should throw your hands up in defeat. If you have the right skills and you can pass an interview, trust the process.
Focus on building genuine relationships, skills [ https://substack.com/redirect/3d9a4c59-fb00-41c4-a7aa-fcda1b010b87?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ], and pushing yourself without losing heart.
Wherever you are in your job-searching journey, pick a few tactical steps from the list above and execute. Right now‚Äîfind a meet-up and attend the next event, join a data community, spend time getting to know the space, and when you‚Äôre ready, start sharing what you‚Äôre learning.
With that, I want to say thank you for reading.

Join My Data Engineering And Data Science Discord
If you‚Äôre looking to talk more about data engineering, data science, breaking into your first job, and finding other like minded data specialists. Then you should join the Seattle Data Guy discord!
We are now over 8000 members!
Join My Technical Consultants Community
If you‚Äôre a data consultant or considering becoming one then you should join the Technical Freelancer Community! We have over 1500 members!
You‚Äôll find plenty of free resources you can access to expedite your journey as a technical consultant as well as be able to talk to other consultants about questions you may have!
Articles Worth Reading
There are thousands of new articles posted daily all over the web! I have spent a lot of time sifting through some of these articles as well as TechCrunch and companies tech blog and wanted to share some of my favorites!
Incremental Load vs Full Load ETL: Key Differences + Examples
ETL and ELT are two widely used data integration techniques. Both methods involve extracting and consolidating data from multiple sources to a single destination. Many organizations prefer the ETL method: it is more compatible with legacy systems and supports transformations before loading, providing more control over data quality and consistency.
Choosing the right data loading strategy is critical for efficient ETL processing. There are several types of data loading processes, including full refresh, full load, and incremental load.
Here, you will find a detailed comparison of incremental load vs full load. Using this information, you can select the loading approach that is better suited to optimize your ETL pipeline [ https://substack.com/redirect/17ecc507-32d9-4a61-abba-9687b4d25865?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ] and meet your organizational requirements.
Read More Here [ https://substack.com/redirect/132c7b8c-5eb3-4b64-bc5b-f6ebb91adc72?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]
How to tell a story with data
By Torsten Walbaum  and Tessa Xie  
As long as humans have existed, they have told stories. For example, the cave paintings in Lascaux, France, are over 30,000 years old and show traces of early graphical storytelling.
And stories still play a central role in our lives today. Ask yourself:
How much do you remember from the last slide deck you saw at work? Probably not much
But how much do you remember from The Lord of the Rings or The Office [or whatever book / movie you like]? Chances are, you can quote entire scenes
If you want to get your point across and make a lasting impression, you need to wrap it in a narrative. Sometimes, people who work with data think they‚Äôre an exception to this. Data represents cold, hard facts ‚Äì that should be convincing enough, no?
Read More Here [ https://substack.com/redirect/8181d67a-d4f8-4e92-8892-4920237e1bc3?j=eyJ1IjoiNTFkc2s3In0.TG_s5GaRal_EYLFDF-UYKHL5eEiDcX8TdL6-5nynlYA ]

Subject: Network Marketing Plan for Skincare Line
Body Text:
To develop a skincare product line that works as a network marketing
agency, you will need to create a detailed strategy and implement systems
that leverage the power of direct sales through independent distributors.
Here's a step-by-step guide to achieving this:

üòéüòéDeveloping the Network Marketing Model**

üí≤Define Your Unique Selling Proposition (USP)
 Identify what makes your skincare products unique (e.g., organic
ingredients, innovative formulas, proven results).
 Ensure your USP is clear and compelling to both consumers and potential
distributors.

üí≤Develop a Compensation Plan
Create a fair and attractive compensation plan for your distributors.
 Include elements such as retail profit, commissions, bonuses, and
incentives for performance.

üí≤Create a Distributor Onboarding Process
Develop training materials, including a comprehensive welcome guide,
product information, and marketing tips.
 Offer ongoing training and support through webinars, workshops, and
mentoring programs.

üí≤Build a Distributor Portal
 Develop an online portal where distributors can place orders, track their
sales, access marketing materials, and communicate with your team.

üòéüòé Product Development and Manufacturing

üí≤Develop Product Recipes
 Formulate high-quality sugar scrubs and salt scrubs with beneficial
ingredients.
 Ensure consistency and quality in production.

üí≤Source Ingredients and Packaging
 Find reliable suppliers for ingredients and packaging materials.
 Maintain high standards for both product efficacy and presentation.

üí≤Manage Production and Inventory
 Establish efficient manufacturing processes to meet demand.
 Implement inventory management systems to track stock levels and reorder
supplies as needed.

üòéüòéMarketing and Promotion

üí≤Develop Marketing Campaigns**
 Plan and execute marketing campaigns to promote the products and the
network marketing opportunity.
Utilize social media, email marketing, and content marketing to reach a
wide audience.

üí≤Collaborate with Influencers and Bloggers
Partner with influencers and bloggers to review and promote your products.
Provide them with free products and incentives to share their experiences.

üí≤Create and Manage Email Marketing Campaigns**
   - Build an email list of potential customers and distributors.
   - Send regular newsletters with product updates, promotions, and success
stories.

üòéüòéSocial Media Management

üí≤Create Content
Develop engaging content (photos, videos, infographics) for Instagram,
Facebook, and Pinterest.
Share behind-the-scenes looks at the product development process, customer
testimonials, and beauty tips.

üí≤Engage with Followers
Respond to comments and messages promptly.
Create a community by engaging with followers and encouraging
user-generated content.

üí≤Monitor Analytics
Track social media performance metrics and adjust strategies based on the
data.
Use tools like Hootsuite or Buffer to schedule posts and analyze engagement.

üòéüòéRecruiting and Training Distributors

üí≤Identify Potential Distributors
Target individuals who are passionate about skincare and have a strong
social media presence.
 Use social media ads, referrals, and networking events to find potential
recruits.

üí≤Provide Training and Support
 Offer comprehensive training on the products, the business model, and
effective sales techniques.
  Provide ongoing support through regular check-ins, additional training
sessions, and a supportive community.

üòéüòéScaling the Business**

üí≤Leverage Technology
Use CRM (Customer Relationship Management) software to manage distributor
relationships and track sales.
Implement e-commerce solutions to streamline the ordering process for
customers and distributors.

üí≤Expand Product Line
Introduce new products regularly to keep the product line fresh and
exciting.
Conduct market research to identify trends and customer needs.

üí≤Optimize Operations
Continuously improve production processes to increase efficiency and reduce
costs.
Ensure quality control measures are in place to maintain product standards.

üòéüòéPreparing for Meetings

Weekly Meeting Agenda:
1. Review key metrics (sales, new recruits, social media engagement).
2. Discuss progress on current projects and tasks.
3. Analyze feedback from customers and distributors.
4. Plan upcoming marketing campaigns and events.
5. Identify challenges and brainstorm solutions.
6. Set goals and tasks for the next week.

üòéüòéQuarterly Goals
üììQ1: Establish Foundation
   - Launch the product line and network marketing opportunity.
   - Recruit and train initial distributors.
   - Build a strong social media presence.

üììQ2: Growth and Expansion
   - Increase the number of active distributors.
   - Expand marketing efforts to include paid ads and influencer
collaborations.
   - Introduce new product variations.

üììQ3: Diversification and Scaling
   - Launch on additional platforms like Etsy.
   - Develop partnerships with complementary brands.
   - Scale production capabilities to meet growing demand.

üììQ4: Consolidation and Profit Maximization
   - Analyze annual performance and identify key success factors.
   - Refine marketing strategies based on data and feedback.
   - Maximize holiday sales with targeted campaigns.
   - Plan for the next year‚Äôs growth with new goals and strategies.

üòéüòéStandard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for Franchising

üìÇDocument Processes
   - Write detailed SOPs for every aspect of the business, including
product development, marketing, sales, and customer service.
   - Ensure the SOPs are clear, concise, and easy to follow.

üìÇDevelop Training Programs
   - Create comprehensive training programs for franchisees to ensure they
understand and can implement the SOPs.
   - Provide ongoing support and training updates.

üìÇImplement Quality Control
   - Establish quality control measures to maintain consistency across all
franchises.
   - Conduct regular audits to ensure compliance with the SOPs.

üìÇCreate a Franchise Support System
   - Develop a support system to assist franchisees with any issues they
may encounter.
   - Provide access to marketing materials, training resources, and a
community of other franchisees.

üëåüí∏üìöüéà
By following these steps, you can develop a successful skincare product
line that operates as a network marketing agency and prepare effectively
for weekly and quarterly meetings with investors.

Subject: Aryuvedic shampoo recipe + basic 4C haircare
Body Text:
Yes, Ayurvedic remedies can be highly effective for moisturizing and
hydrating type 4C hair. Here are some Ayurvedic ingredients you can add to
your shampoo formula to enhance moisture and hydration:

### Ayurvedic Ingredients
1. **Amla (Indian Gooseberry) Extract**: Rich in vitamin C and
antioxidants, amla strengthens hair follicles, promotes hair growth, and
adds moisture.
2. **Bhringraj Extract**: Known as the "king of herbs" for hair growth,
bhringraj helps to condition the scalp and hair, improving moisture
retention.
3. **Brahmi Extract**: Helps to nourish the hair roots, strengthens the
hair, and adds a protective layer that helps in retaining moisture.
4. **Neem Extract**: Known for its antifungal and antibacterial properties,
neem helps maintain scalp health and adds moisture to dry hair.
5. **Fenugreek (Methi) Extract**: Contains mucilage which provides slip and
helps with detangling, as well as conditioning and moisturizing properties.
6. **Aloe Vera Extract**: Enhances moisture content and soothes the scalp,
providing hydration and slip.
7. **Ashwagandha Extract**: Strengthens hair and helps to maintain scalp
health, indirectly supporting moisture retention.

### Updated Ingredient List for Amazon
1. Decyl Glucoside
2. Coco Glucoside
3. Polyquaternium-10
4. Hydrolyzed Silk Protein
5. Glycerin
6. Panthenol (Pro-Vitamin B5)
7. Dimethicone
8. Jojoba Oil
9. Xanthan Gum
10. Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
11. Citric Acid
12. Distilled Water
13. Phenoxyethanol (Preservative)
14. Ethylhexylglycerin (Preservative)
15. Sodium Benzoate (Preservative)
16. Potassium Sorbate (Preservative)
17. Fragrance or Essential Oils (optional)
18. Aloe Vera Gel
19. Shea Butter
20. Argan Oil
21. Marshmallow Root Extract
22. Honeyquat
23. Silk Amino Acids
24. Babassu Oil
25. Amla Extract
26. Bhringraj Extract
27. Brahmi Extract
28. Neem Extract
29. Fenugreek Extract
30. Ashwagandha Extract

### Instructions for Manufacturing with Ayurvedic Ingredients
1. **Mix Surfactants**:
   - In a large mixing tank, combine Decyl Glucoside and Coco Glucoside.
Mix until uniform.

2. **Add Conditioning Agents**:
   - Slowly add Polyquaternium-10, Hydrolyzed Silk Protein, and Silk Amino
Acids while stirring continuously to ensure even dispersion.

3. **Incorporate Moisturizers and Emollients**:
   - Add Glycerin, Panthenol, Dimethicone, Jojoba Oil, Aloe Vera Gel, Shea
Butter, Argan Oil, Babassu Oil, and Honeyquat. Mix until fully incorporated.

4. **Blend Thickeners**:
   - Gradually add Xanthan Gum and Guar Hydroxypropyltrimonium Chloride
while mixing continuously to prevent clumping. Allow the mixture to hydrate
and thicken.

5. **Add Ayurvedic Extracts**:
   - Add Amla Extract, Bhringraj Extract, Brahmi Extract, Neem Extract,
Fenugreek Extract, and Ashwagandha Extract. Ensure thorough mixing to
evenly distribute these extracts.

6. **Adjust pH**:
   - Measure the pH of the mixture and adjust to 5.0-5.5 using Citric Acid.
This pH range is optimal for hair and scalp health.

7. **Add Water**:
   - Slowly add distilled water while mixing to achieve the desired
consistency.

8. **Add Preservatives**:
   - This step should be done by the manufacturer. Ensure proper
preservation by adding recommended preservatives like Phenoxyethanol and
Ethylhexylglycerin.

9. **Fragrance (Optional)**:
   - If using, add fragrance or essential oils at this stage and mix
thoroughly.

10. **Quality Control and Packaging**:
    - Conduct quality control tests to ensure the product meets all
specifications.
    - Package the shampoo in appropriate containers, ensuring they are
sealed properly for shipment.

By incorporating these Ayurvedic ingredients, your shampoo will provide
enhanced moisture, hydration, and nourishment, making it particularly
beneficial for type 4C hair and helping your product stand out in the
market.
